My husband kept forgetting my birthday, so this year I forgot him. For 3 years straight, Danny would act surprised when my birthday rolled around. First year he said work was crazy and he'd make it up to me. Second year he claimed his phone died so he lost track of dates. Last year he literally asked me why I seemed upset on February 15th, like he had no clue it was the day after my birthday. Meanwhile, this guy remembered every sports stat from 1995 and could tell you exactly when his favorite show aired each week. He had phone reminders for oil changes, dentist appointments, even when to water his plants. But somehow my birthday was this impossible thing to keep track of. My friends kept telling me to just remind him or send hints, but that felt pathetic. If some someone cares about you, they remember what matters to you without being nagged about it. This year, I decided to test something. Two weeks before my birthday, I started dropping hints everywhere. I left my birth certificate on the kitchen counter. I circled February 14th on the calendar with a big red heart. I even mentioned it during dinner. My birthday is coming up soon, I said, while we ate tacos. He just nodded and kept scrolling his phone. The week before, I got more obvious. I showed him a dress online and said this would be perfect for my birthday dinner next week. He mumbled something about it. Being nice and went back to watching TV. Three days before, I literally said, so what are we doing for my birthday Thursday? He looked confused and asked, what's Thursday? When I told him it was my birthday, he slapped his forehead like he always did and said, right? Yeah, I've been so busy with work stuff. Thursday morning came. I woke up expecting something, anything, maybe flowers by my bedside or breakfast in bed. Nothing. He got dressed, kissed my cheek and said he'd be back late because of a client dinner. Not even a happy birthday. I sat there in my pajamas until noon feeling stupid for hoping things would be different this year. Then I remembered something. His birthday was exactly one month later, March 14th. And for the past four years, I'd thrown him surprise parties, bought expensive gifts, took days off work to plan.

I let my daughter dye her hair blue. My sister called me a bad mom until her kid told me the truth. When Emma asked if she could dye her hair blue for her 13th birthday, I said, sure. It's just hair, right? She'd been begging me for weeks, showing me Pinterest photos of these gorgeous ocean blue highlights. At target. We picked out some semi permanent dye that would wash out in a month. She was so excited, she could barely sit still while I painted the streaks in our tiny bathroom. The next morning at breakfast, she kept flipping her hair and grinning at herself in the toaster reflection. I made her favorite blueberry pancakes, and she kept saying how the blue and her hair match the berries perfectly. Was honestly the happiest I'd seen her since her dad moved out last year. But when we showed up at my sister Beth's house for Sunday dinner, everything went sideways fast. Beth took one look at Emma, and her face just dropped. He pulled me into the kitchen while Emma was playing with her cousins and started going off about how irresponsible I was being. What kind of message does this send? She whispered harshly, gesturing toward the living room. She's going to look like some delinquent at school. I tried explaining it was just temporary hair dye, that Emma was still getting straight A's and playing violin, but Beth wouldn't hear it. She kept shaking her head and Muttering about how I was clear, really struggling as a single mom and needed to set better boundaries. The whole dinner was awkward after that, with Beth making passive aggressive comments about certain parenting choices every time Emma's hair caught the light. When we got home that night, Emma seemed deflated. She kept touching her hair and asking if I thought it looked stupid. I reassured her it looked amazing, but I could tell Beth's reaction had gotten to her. That's when I decided to call my mom to vent about the whole thing. Mom listened patiently while I ranted about Beth being judgmental. Then she got quiet for a moment. Honey, she said carefully, there's something you should probably know about your sister's situation. Apparently, Beth had been calling mom almost daily, crying about her twelve year old son, Tyler. He'd been getting into fights at school, his grades were dropping, and she'd found vape cartridges hidden in his backpack.

My brother's wedding planner called. Your family canceled your invitation, but asked to keep the 50 thousand dollar deposit you paid. I said cancel the entire wedding. The call came Tuesday morning while I was editing a commercial in my home studio. This is Renee from Perfect Day Planning calling about Jared's wedding next month. Her voice sounded uncomfortable. I have some difficult news. Your family contacted us yesterday and asked us to remove you from the guest list entirely. They mentioned some family disagreements and said you wouldn't be welcome at the ceremony or reception. I paused my editing software. My family still sees me as the 29 year old college dropout who threw his life away to become a freelance videographer. What they don't know is what I actually do with all that video equipment filling my garage. However, Renee continued nervously, they also specifically requested to keep the 50 thousand dollar deposit you paid for the wedding videography pack. Missus Ruth said the family had already allocated those funds to other wedding expenses and couldn't possibly return them. I leaned back in my chair looking at the wall of awards behind me. Emmy nominations, industry recognition, contracts with Fortune 500 company. My little video hobby had quietly become a 15 million dollar production company over the past eight years. Renee, I need to ask you something important. What's the name of your wedding venue? The Riverside Manor downtown. And who owns that property? I heard papers shuffling on Her end. Um, it's listed under Sunset Holdings, LLC, right? What about your catering company? Golden Plate Catering Services. Also owned by longer pause. Sunset Holdings, LLC as well. Wait, what's going on here? The photography studio handling the wedding photos. Elite Moment Studio. Oh, my god. That's also Sunset Holdings. The florist providing all the arrangements, Bella's Garden Creations. That's. That's you, too, isn't it? The DJ company, the luxury transportation service, the rehearsal dinner venue, even the hotel block for out of town guests. All owned by Sunset Holdings, LLC. Which is my company. Renee's voice went up an octave. Mister Ruth, are you telling me that you own every single vender for this wedding? I'm telling you that for the past eight months, I've been secretly funding my brother's entire dream wedding through shell companies I created. Every vendor, every service, every single detail of this wedding, all paid for by me through different LLCs, so my family wouldn't.

My parents said, now that you've turned 16, you're on your own. I replied, okay. Within a month, they took those words back. On the morning of my 16th birthday, my parents staged what they called an independence intervention. They sat me down at the kitchen table with printed power points, slides and everything. Starting today, you're completely on your own, my mother announced, sliding a laminated card across the table that read, welcome to the real world. No more car rides to anywhere. You walk, bike, or figure it out. No more cooked meals either. The kitchen is available, but you buy and prepare your own food. No more laundry service. No more wake up calls. No more anything. We're done enabling your dependence. My father nodded sagely, adding, you'll thank us when you're thriving at 30. I studied their smug faces. Okay, I said calmly, already planning my next moves. Complete independence. They smiled, missing the careful phrasing entirely. Within 48 hours, I'd secured a job at a tech repair shop at paid surprisingly well for someone who could fix literally anything electronic. By week two, I'd negotiated a deal with my elderly neighbor, Missus Kapoor, for food. I do her grocery runs and tech support in exchange for home cooked meals. Meanwhile, the household began its slow descent into chaos. First, the Wi-Fi crashed during Dad's critical zoom presentation with Hong Kong. He stood outside my locked door for 20 minutes, pleading, just this once, buddy. It's important. But I had headphones on at dinner, he slammed his fist on the table. You knew I had that meeting. Why didn't you help me? I don't live here anymore, remember? I'm just a tenant who pays no rent. Would you fix your neighbor's W I F I? I replied, eating missus Kapoor's dumplings. Mom's phone stopped receiving emails, and I refused to fix it for her, making her miss three work deadlines. This is sabotage, she accused, cornering me in the hallway. You're being vindictive, you said. I'm on my own. That means household tech support isn't my job anymore, I said, walking past her to my paid shift. The refrigerator's water filter I'd secretly maintained for three years started dispensing gray water. Mom gagged on it during her morning coffee, then spent $400 on a can't see plumber visits before realizing it was just the filter. Why didn't you tell us? She demanded. You cut me off from family support. Why would I maintain household infrastructure for people I don't live with? The garage door opener needed reprogramming after a power outage trapping mom's car. She missed her promotion interview while waiting for the repair guy. This is your fault! She screamed through my door. You've made your point. What point? You said, I'm not your responsibility, so your house problems aren't mine. Tell! They were losing their sanity. A complete system collapse happened during their 20th anniversary party, which they'd foolishly decided to host at home. The Printer wouldn't connect to Mom's laptop. Get in here now! She shrieked from their bedroom. Sorry, I don't work here. I'm an independent adult with my own job. I called back, heading out to my shift. She handwrote 30 menus, cramping her hand so badly she needed ice. Quietly sobbing from frustration, the smart home system I'd configured started playing death metal at full volume instead of jazz. Dad frantically pressed every button on his phone while guests covered their ears. What did you do? He roared up the stairs. Nothing. I don't live here anymore. According to you, I text

I gave my mother in law the honesty she demanded, then begged me to keep lying. My wedding reception was perfect until my mother in law, Lydia, grabbed the microphone during toast. She had already spent 10 minutes telling everyone how I trapped her precious baby boy when she turned to me in front of 200 people. You wanna know your biggest problem, sweetie? You are so fake with all that phony sweetness it makes me want to puke. Everyone stopped eating and stared at us. All that please and thank you garbage and pretending you actually care what people think when we all know you are just a manipulative little gold digger. You are going to stop lying and tell me the absolute truth about everything. I will make your life so miserable you will wish you never met my son. I looked at my horrified guests and my embarrassed husband before responding calmly into the microphone she had shoved at me. You want me to never lie and always tell you the complete truth about everything? She crossed her arms and smirked at me. That is exactly what I want. And I want it to start right now. I smiled at my new husband and then at her. Okay then. Brutal honesty. It is Thanksgiving. She made the mistake of asking why I seemed so quiet lately. Honestly, it's because I found out you told everyone at your church that I had an abortion when I have never Even been pregnant. So now 30 random strangers pray for my murdered baby every Sunday. The entire table went silent as Lydia went pale. I, I, um. He stumbled. I don't want to hear your excuses. They'll just be useless, I told her. Desperate to change the subject, she asked if everyone was enjoying her famous Turkey dinner. Of course I gave her the honesty. She demanded. No, your gravy tastes like you mixed flour or with hot dog water. And I can still hear the Turkey gobbling. Everyone stopped chewing, and I pushed my plate away. I would feed this to the dog, but I think that would be animal abuse. Later, she asked if her new dress looked nice for the family photos. You look like you got dressed in the dark, and that colour makes your skin look like raw chicken. Her face went red as I continued. Also, the way it stretched across your body really shows every single fat roll you're trying to hide. Her sister laughed so hard that she spit her wine across the table. When she asked if people were having a good time, I kept being honest. Nobody really wants to be here because your house smells like cat piss. Finally, he asked why nobody wanted to go Black Friday shopping with her this year. It's because last year you pepper sprayed a grandmother over a TV that wasn't even on sale. You also always make every 1 hold your purse while You try on clothes that are clearly three sizes too small. By Christmas, she was trying really hard to avoid asking me direct questions, but she slipped up constantly. When she asked if I like the sweater she spent two months knitting, I gave her the brutal honesty she had demanded. It looks like you learn to knit during a seizure. She started tearing up, but I didn't feel bad for her because she had asked for the truth. At dinner, she asked if we like the Christmas decorations that she had spent thousands of dollars on. No, your house looks like Christmas threw up after eating nothing but glitter and tinsel for a month. Her husband nodded in agreement. She asked if people

What did you do when your stepmom said you'd never be her real daughter? Gloria sorted the family photos on the mantle. She put her biological kids on the left and moved mine to the right. It's easier to keep track this way, she said, making sure I heard every word. Dad just sat there watching TV like nothing happened. I felt my face burn, but stayed quiet. Every holiday card she sent out had the same arrangement. Her real family, then my name tacked on at the end. I was 15, and those little cuts hurt more than I wanted to admit. Dad never said anything about it. When I turned 17, I heard Gloria telling her sister I would vanish after graduation. She's not interested in family history, just biding time until she can leave. I stood frozen in the hallway, feeling like I'd. And punched. But Gloria had talked for years about being adopted herself. She'd given up finding her birth mother. After decades of dead ends, that rejection still ate at her. That's when I decided to show her what real daughters actually do. I started volunteering at the senior center, teaching computers. That's where I met Ruth, who was struggling with the mouse and keyboard. She mentioned she'd given up a baby girl in 1962 at Riverside Hospital. My heart started pounding so hard, I thought Ruth would hear it. But I kept my voice steady and asked her more questions. The timeline matched. Gloria Perfectly. Gloria was getting crueler every week. She introduced me as my husband's daughter at free gathering, and I'd watch people's faces change when they realized I wasn't really hers. She made me take separate family photos so she could have some without me. At my high school awards night, she told people she was there supporting her husband while I gave my valedictorian speech. I saw other parents crying with pride while mine sat there like she was at someone else's event. Dad tried defending me once, but Gloria told him to stop being dramatic. He never tried again. I almost quit helping Ruth that week because maybe I'd never matter to Gloria. But Ruth was running out of time. Her doctor had given her maybe a year. She'd never tried finding her daughter because computers confused her and she couldn't afford help. Every Saturday for eight months, I taught her how to use DNA websites. We uploaded her information to the same site Gloria had used years before. Then we waited. Ruth got sicker each week, and I got more desperate. I'd lie awake thinking, what if this wasn't Gloria's mother? And I was. Wait. Sting. A dying woman's final months on false hope. Then the match came through. Mother and daughter with 99.8% certainty. Ruth cried so hard she couldn't breathe. But Gloria hadn't logged into the site for five years. Ruth begged me not to tell Gloria because rejection would kill her faster than the cancer. Gloria's 60th birthday was in three weeks. Though dad was throwing a party with 40 relatives coming, this was Ruth's only chance. I promised I'd bring her myself. The morning of Gloria's birthday, Ruth could barely walk. I practically carried her from my car while my hands shook. At the party, Gloria was lecturing everyone about how family bonds come from blood, not paperwork. I felt sick hearing it, knowing it was an other dig at me. That's when Ruth shuffled into our backyard. I'm looking for Gloria Marie, born March 15th, 1962, Ruth said, her voice barely audible. Gloria turned around, looking annoyed at the interruption. That's me, but you're at the wrong party. Ruth didn't say anything. She just pulled out her phone with trembling hands and showed the screen to Gloria. I held my breath. The yard went completely silent. Gloria stared at the screen showing the maternal match. Her face went white. This is fake, Gloria said, but her voice cracked.

video_description: My mom wished I‚Äôd disappear from her life, so I gave her what she wanted and now she‚Äôs miserable.#reddit#reddit_tiktok#redditreadings#askreddit#fyp#foryoupage#redditstorytime#Reddit#fypage#shortstory
voice_to_text: My mom wished that I would disappear from her life, so I gave her exactly what she wanted, and now she's miserable. My mother weaponized disappointment like other parents used praise. She'd sigh when introducing me to friends, hang up on me mid sentence if I wasn't saying something impressive enough, and her house was filled with photos of my perfect cousin Sarah, who she always compared me to. Even her compliments came wrapped in poison. You look pretty today, which is rare. She started early when I brought home a report card with straight A's and 1 B+, drove to school, and demanded they remove me from honors classes because obviously I couldn't handle the pressure. The month after that, I won second place at the science fair, and she told the winner's mother, loud enough for everyone to hear, that my daughter probably cheated and still couldn't win. How disappointing. I got into my dream college. She called admissions and tried to decline my acceptance because state school would be more appropriate for someone of your abilities. She didn't even leave my boyfriend out of it, announcing at family dinner that he was doing charity work by dating down. When I bought my first house, she posted on Facebook that I'd finally found a place that matches my low standards, with photos highlighting every flaw. If I even confronted her about any of this, call other relatives immediately. I'm worried about her mental health. She keeps imagining I Said terrible things when all I've ever done is support her. Maybe she needs some professional help. The breaking point came last winter when my appendix burst and I was rushed into emergency surgery. I called my mother while terrified and in pain, begging her to come give me some assurance. She sighed at my voice and said, I won't come. Do you even realize how disappointed I am that my only child can't even stay healthy? Sarah's mother never has to deal with hospital visits. She hung up before I could respond. While nurses prepped me for surgery, I checked Facebook one last time. My mom had posted 10 minutes after our call. Some days I wish I could just start over with a child who doesn't constantly disappoint me. It's like I might as well not have one at all. My own friends were texting me screenshots, horrified that my mother would write this while I was being wheeled into surgery. That when something inside me snapped into place, she wanted to act like she didn't have a child so I'd give her exactly what she asked for. I decided to lean into her declaration. If she wished she didn't have a child, then I'd honor that wish. I started simple. Changed my voicemail to a memorial message. You've reached the memorial line for Helen's daughter. Please leave condolences after the tone. Then I had funeral flowers delivered to her house, laying the foundation perfectly. Mom called me 37 times that day I didn't answer. Next, I sent sympathy cards to all our relatives, thinking of you during this difficult time of loss. They read. I signed them, A friend who cares. Whenever I ran into her church friends at the grocery store, I'd mention casually that I was planning a memorial service. Since mom declared she might as well not have a child, I figured I should honor her wishes. I'd say with a sad smile, it's what she wanted. Words spread fast through her social circles. People started asking mom about the service. She tried explaining I wasn't actually dead, but that made her look even worse. So you said you don't have a child, but you do? They'd ask. That's really messed up, Helen. The masterpiece came together when I scheduled my memorial for the same day as her charity club.

video_description: My husband assaulted me in front of his entire family and no one stood up to him, but my daughter... #reddit#reddit_tiktok#redditreadings#askreddit#fyp#foryoupage#redditstorytime#Reddit#fypage#shortstory
voice_to_text: My husband assaulted me in front of his entire family and no one stood up to him. But my daughter did something that made him turn pale. It was Thanksgiving at his parents house and I should have known better than to show up with store bought dinner rolls. For eight years of marriage to Derek, I had Learned that everything had to be perfect in front of his family or there would be consequences later. But I had been pulling 12 hour shifts at the hospital all week and barely had time to shower, let alone bake homemade bread. His mother, Patricia, made the first comment. As I set the plastic container on her perfectly set dining table, she lifted one roll with her manicured fingers like it might contaminate her entire meal. Well, she said, loud enough for the entire room to hear, I suppose not everyone has time for family traditions anymore. Twenty two family members were crammed into that dining room. His parents, both brothers with their wives, six kids ranging from toddlers to teenagers, and various aunts and uncles who had driven in from neighboring towns. All of them turned to stare at me like I had committed some unforgivable sin. I forced a smile and explained that I had been working overtime at the hospital. Three nurses had called in sick with the flu, and someone had to cover the emergency department. I thought they would understand. His father was a retired police officer. His brothers worked construction. They knew about demanding jobs. But Derek's face was already turning that familiar shade of red that meant trouble was coming. His jaw clenched the way it always did when he thought I had embarrassed him. The vein in his temple started throbbing. You always have an excuse, he said loudly enough to cut through every conversation in the room. The football game on TV suddenly seemed too loud. Someone's fork clinked against their plate. One of the toddlers asked for more juice, but nobody moved to help him. All eyes were on us. Now. I'm not making excuses, I said as calmly as I could manage. I'm explaining why I didn't have time to bake this week. That's when he hit me. The slap echoed through the dining room like a gunshot. My cheek exploded in pain, and I could taste blood where my teeth had cut the inside of my lip. The force of it knocked me sideways, and I had to grab the back of a chair to keep from falling. Complete silence fell over the room. Not one person moved. Not one person spoke. His father stared at his plate like it held the secrets of the universe. His mother suddenly developed an intense interest in folding and refolding her napkin. His brothers exchanged a quick glance, but immediately looked away. Even the children had gone completely quiet. Don't you ever embarrass me like that again! Derek hissed through clenched teeth. That's When my sixteen year old daughter Chloe stood up from the kids table in the corner, she had been living with us for two years since her father died in a motorcycle accident.

What shocking thing did someone reveal when inhaling laughing gas? I thought I knew everything about my husband Sergio after 12 years of marriage. Turns out I didn't know the most important thing. We were at the oral surgeon's office getting his wisdom teeth removed, all four at once. Because Sergio always like to get things over with quickly. I sat in the waiting room scrolling through my phone and thinking about what soft foods to pick pick up on the way home. Just another Tuesday afternoon in our normal suburban life. The nurse called me back after about an hour. Sergio was in recovery, still pretty looped from the laughing gas and whatever else they'd given him. His cheeks were stuffed with gauze and his eyes were glassy. But he was awake and mumbling something I couldn't understand. He's doing great, the nurse said. Just needs a few more minutes before you can take him home. I sat next to him and took his hand. That's when things got weird. Instead of squeezing my hand back like he always did, Sergio pulled away and started looking around the room frantically. Where's Nathan, he slurred through the gauze. I need Nathan. Nathan was his best friend since college. They worked at this I'm accounting firm and play basketball together every Saturday. I figured the drugs were just making him confused. Nathan's at work, honey, I'm here. It's me, Sonia. But Sergio kept shaking his head and trying to sit up. The nurse had to hold him down. No, no, no. Need to tell Nathan. Need to tell him about that night. What night? I asked even. No, he probably wouldn't remember any of this later. Our wedding night. His words were getting clearer as he got more agitated. I left the reception, told you I was checking on the hotel room. But I went to Nathan, had to see Nathan. My stomach started feeling weird, but I told myself it was just random drug talk. People say all kinds of nonsense when they're high. The nurse gave me a look like she'd seen this before, patients revealing secrets they never tell sober. Sergio kept going. And when Joyce was born, you were sleeping. And I snuck out to the parking lot. Nathan was waiting in his car. I needed him there. Always need him there. Joyce was our daughter. She was 8 now and the light of both our lives. Why was Sergio talking about Nathan during her birth? My hands were starting to shake. First anniversary dinner, told you I got called into work, but I didn't. Went to Nathan's apartment. We watched our movie. We always watch our movie on important days. The nurse quietly excused herself, probably sensing this was getting too personal. Sergio reached for my hand again, but this time his touch felt different. Foreign. Love Nathan so much. Love him more than anything, but love Sonia, too. Love them both. Why can't I love Them both. The drugs were wearing off enough that tears were rolling down his face, mixing with a drool from his numb mouth. I sat there frozen, trying to process what I was hearing. My husband of 12 years, the father of my child, the man I built my whole life around. How long, I whispered, even though I wasn't sure I wanted to know. Forever since junior year, before I even met you.

My daughter came home crying every day from school because her best friend started ignoring her after getting a new iPhone that my daughter couldn't afford. Emma had been best friends with Zoe since second grade. They did everything together, walked to school, ate lunch at the same table, had sleepovers every weekend. My daughter would come home with stories about their inside jokes and secret handshakes. They were inseparable. But everything changed when Zoe got an iPhone 15 for her 13th birthday. Suddenly, Emma wasn't getting invited to hang out anymore. At lunch, Zoe would sit with the girls who had fancy phones, showing off her new camera and playing games Emma couldn't join because she only had my old flip phone. I came home in tears three days straight, Mom, Zoe won't even look at me. I'm boring now because I can't text her or be in the group chat. It broke my heart watching my confident daughter shrink into herself. I worked two jobs just to keep us afloat after the divorce. There was no way I could afford a 600 dollar phone for a 13 year old. But seeing Emma's face every day, knowing she was eating lunch alone while her former best friend posted Instagram stories with new friends made me desperate. That's when I remembered something my grandmother taught me about friendship. She used to say real friends don't need expensive things to connect. They need shared experiences and genuine care for Each other. I had an idea. Instead of trying to compete with technology, I would give Emma something Zoe's iPhone couldn't, real adventure. I started planning surprise activities for Emma and whoever wanted to join. Many road trips to the beach, camping in our backyard, teaching her to bake my grandmother's secret cookie recipe. The first weekend, only Emma and I went hiking. But she seemed happier than she'd been in weeks, taking photos with my old digital camera and collecting pretty rocks. She posted one blurry photo on her rarely used social media with the caption, adventures with mom. Monday at school, three different girls asked Emma about her weekend. Turns out, while everyone else was stuck inside on their phones, Emma had stories to tell, real stories about getting lost on the trail and finding a hidden waterfall. Within two weeks, Emma had new friends asking to join our weekend adventures. Girls who were tired of just staring at screens wanted to come camping, learn to bake, go on photo walks around town. The turning point came during our third weekend camping trip. We had four girls with us roasting marshmallows.

video_description: My phone buzzed while I was walking home. It was my best friend You need to see this...#reddit#reddit_tiktok#redditreadings#askreddit#fyp#foryoupage#redditstorytime#Reddit#fypage#shortstory
voice_to_text: My phone buzzed while I was walking home. It was my best friend. You need to see this before tomorrow or everything changes. I'm like, what the hell, Maya? What's so urgent that can't wait? She goes, no, seriously, get over here now. Trust me, you need to see this. So I'm walking to her apartment thinking someone died or something. The whole way there, I'm trying to figure out what could be so bad that she can't just tell me over text. Maya's not dramatic usually, so this has to be serious. She opens the door and immediately goes, sit down. She looks genuinely upset, which is freaking me out even more. She's got her laptop out on the kitchen table and she's just staring at, at me. Promise me you won't freak out. Now I'm really panicked. I'm thinking maybe someone posted revenge of me or something eaily horrible. She turns the screen and shows me Adrian's Instagram. There's a post from 3 hours ago of him at some restaurant holding hands with this girl across the table. The caption says, 2 years together and still feels like the honeymoon phase. Staring at it confused because we've been together for two years, like what are the odds it's just a coincidence? Then I look closer at the girl and my stomach drops. It's my coworker, Lila. The same Lila who sits two cubicles away from me. The same Lila who's been weird around me lately, always asking about My schedule if Adrian and I are happy, what we did last weekend. Random stuff that seemed innocent at the time. Maya goes there's more and scrolls down to the comments. Adrian's mom commented, so happy for you both with heart emojis. His sister wrote about time you made it official. His college room mate wrote, finally introducing us to the real one. The real one. Like I'm some fake placeholder girlfriend. I'm just sitting there like what the actual f. Everyone in his family knows about this girl and I had no clue. How long has this been going on? That's when Maya shows me Lila's Instagram. She's got posts going back months. Her and Adrian at concerts I thought he was going to with his guy friends. I'm at the beach house his family rents every summer that he told me was family only this year. There's even a photo of them at his cousin's graduation party in may, the same party he told me I couldn't come to because it was just close family. I scroll through more of her posts and see Adrian's friends commenting on everything. People I've met multiple times who apparently know about Lila but never said anything to me. The worst part is I work with this girl every single day. We eat lunch together in the break room. I've been telling her about my relationship problems with.

video_description: My mom called me ungrateful for moving out at 18. So, I decided to test her theory. #reddit#reddit_tiktok#redditreadings#askreddit#fyp#foryoupage#redditstorytime#Reddit#fypage#shortstory
voice_to_text: My mother said on her deathbed, you were never my real child. I stared at her, waiting for some explanation, some context that would make those words make sense. But she just closed her eyes with this peaceful expression, like she'd finally gotten something off her chest. An hour later, she was gone. The funeral was small. My mother didn't have many friends, and I was her only family. Or so I thought. People kept telling me how sorry they were for my loss, how she was such a devoted mother, how proud she must have been of me. I just nodded and smiled. But her last words kept echoing in my head. For three weeks, I couldn't function. I'd wake up at 3:00am replaying that moment. What did she mean? Was I adopted? Did she have an affair? Was there some family secret she took to her grave? My coworkers started asking if I was okay. I'd zone out during meetings, stare at my computer screen for hours without typing a word. My girlfriend Sarah kept suggesting therapy. But how do you explain to a therapist that your dying mother basically told you that you weren't her real kid? I started going through old family photos, looking for clues. Every single picture, my mother looked distant. Even in photos from my childhood birthdays, she had this forced smile, like she was performing the role of a happy mother rather than actually being one. Then I remembered how she used To disappear. Every year on my birthday, she'd make me breakfast, give me presents, sing Happy Birthday. But then around noon, she'd always say she had errands to run. She'd be gone for hours, coming back quiet and sad. I always thought she was visiting my father's grave. But now I wondered. Then I found her old address book. There were names and numbers I didn't recognize, including one entry that just said D. Important dates with a phone number. No last name, no address. Just D. That's when I decided I had to go through everything in her house systematically. I've been putting it off, but I needed answers. I started in her bedroom, going through drawers, closets, boxes, under the bed. Most of it was normal stuff. Old bills, jewelry, clothes that still smelled like her perfume. But then, in the very back of her closet, behind winter coat she never wore, I found a small metal lock box. It was heavy, and when I shook it, I could hear paper shuffling inside. The key was taped underneath her jewelry box. She always hid things in the most obvious places. My hands were shaking as I opened it. Inside were birth certificates. Mine yellowed with age. And another one with the exact same date. Same hospital, same time of birth, but a different name. David Michael Thompson. The mother's name was the same. Margaret Thompson. My mother. I had a twin brother. That wasn't all. There were letters. Dozens of them, written in my mother's handwriting. Birthday cards, Christmas cards, graduation cards, all addressed to my dearest David.

Parents, what do your kids think they're hiding from you? My 14 year old son thinks he's a master of deception, but he has no idea I know about his secret YouTube channel. I discovered it by accident when I was cleaning his room and found a crumpled receipt for a 300 dollar microphone. First I was furious. We just had a talk about responsible spending. But before confronting him, I decided to do some digging. That night after he went to bed, I searched his browser history. There it was, a gaming channel with 50,000 subscribers. My quiet, introverted son who barely I spoke at family dinners was absolutely electric on camera, cracking jokes and entertaining thousands. Instead of shutting it down, I decided to play dumb and secretly support him. Every time he went to study at the library, I knew he was actually recording videos in our basement. I'd intentionally make extra noise upstairs so he'd have to re record, teaching him patience. He complained about background noise ruining his takes. I suggested soundproofing his room for better concentration while studying. He started asking for odd things, green poster board, ring lights, a better webcam. Each time I'd make him present a detailed plan for how these school supplies would improve his grades. His presentations got increasingly elaborate. He even made a Powerpoint about how better lighting would help him read text books more clearly. The best part, every time he uploaded a new video, I'd watch It immediately, my son would sit at dinner casually mentioning how hard his homework was while I knew he just spent three hours trying to beat the final boss in Elden Ring. He got creative with his excuses. Once he told us he needed to join the debate club to improve his public speaking. In reality, he was practicing his commentary skills. When he won most improved speaker at school, I had to bite my tongue. His hundreds of hours of gaming commentary had given him more confidence than any debate club could. One day he mentioned needing a new chair because his back hurt from studying. I knew the real reason. He just hit 100,000 subscribers and was streaming longer. I bought him a gaming chair but labeled it an ergonomic study.

My own mother abandoned me at the airport when I was just 15, all to enjoy a luxurious vacation with her new husband and his kids. You can figure it out. She shrugged. I stood there watching her walk away with her perfect little blended family, dragging their matching designer suitcases toward the gate. She didn't even look back. Not once. I had $23 in my pocket, a dead phone charger, and absolutely nowhere to go in this massive airport. That's when I remembered the business card tucked in my wallet. The one with the fancy logo I've been carrying around for three years. My Aunt Sarah's restaurant card. The sister my mom had been bad mouthing my entire life, calling her a jealous failure. Sarah's a pathetic loser, mom always said. She's jealous of our success and stability. Don't believe anything she tells you about our family. But standing there alone in JFK Terminal 4, watching families rush past me with their vacation excitement, I figured I had nothing left to lose. I found a payphone. Yes, they still exist in airports. And dialed the number with shaking fingers. It rang twice before a warm, professional voice answered. Bella Vista Restaurant. This is Sarah speaking. Aunt Sarah, it's Maya. I'm. I'm in really big trouble right now. The silence lasted forever. Then, in a completely different tone. Baby girl? Maya, where are you? Are you safe? What happened? I started crying. Right there in the middle of the busy Terminal. Mom left me at the airport. She took her new husband and his kids on vacation to Hawaii and just abandoned me here. What terminal are you at? I'm coming to get you right now. You don't understand. I'm at JFK in New York. You're all the way in Chicago. I can't ask you to. Maya, Honey, listen to me carefully. I have three successful restaurants now. I'm not the broke failure your mother told you I was. Exactly where you are. I'm getting on the next available flight. Four hours later, I watched a confident woman in designer jeans and a cashmere coat rush through the arrivals gate, scanning the crowd frantically. She looked exactly like mom, but her eyes were kind instead of cold. When she spotted me, she started running. I've been waiting 10 years for this phone call, she whispered, hugging me so tight I could barely breathe. I've tried reaching you so many times, but your mother blocked every single attempt. To ride to her luxury hotel suite was completely surreal. Sarah explained everything while ordering room service. How she built a successful restaurant empire from nothing. How she been sending birthday cards and Christmas gifts that mom apparently threw away unopened. How she'd even hired a family lawyer once to try for visitation rights. Your mother told everyone in our family that I was a drug addict who couldn't hold a job. Sarah laughed bitterly. Meanwhile, I've been featured in Chicago magazine as entrepreneur Of the year, two years running. That night in the hotel, Sarah showed me years worth of returned letters with refused stamps, photos of elaborate birthday cake she'd made for me each year, and bank statements proving she'd

On my birthday, my boss's son called me into his office and said, here's my surprise for you. You're fired. I left quietly without making a scene, then told my husband to just smiled. Four hours later, panic broke out. 98 missed call. I've been the head chef at Romano's for three years. When I started, it was a struggling family restaurant with two star reviews and empty tables. I transformed everything, rebuilt the menu, trained the staff, sourced local ingredients. Within a year, we were booked solid with a waiting list. But when old Mister Romano died last spring, everything changed. His son Giovanni inherited the place and he had different ideas. Cut costs, use frozen ingredients, fire half the kitchen staff. People can't tell the difference anyway, he'd say. Counting receipts while I fought to maintain the standards that built our reputation. I refuse to compromise our lamb. Also buco was legendary. Our house made pasta brought people from three states over. I wasn't about to ruin that for Giovanni's, the margins. So on my 32nd birthday, after our biggest week ever, he called me into the cramped office above the dining room. Birthday balloons from the staff still hung in the kitchen below. Here's my surprise for you, he said with this smug grin. You're fired effective immediately. You're too difficult to work with. I stood there, soft stained apron still tied around my waist, watching him lean back in his father's old chair like he just Solved world hunger. I didn't argue, didn't cry, just untied my apron, set it on his desk and walked out past the confused prep cooks who'd worked under me for years. The drive home felt endless. Three years of my life gone. My reputation, my team, my recipes all handed over to someone who thought ketchup was a vegetable. My husband, Scott was waiting in our kitchen with a bottle of wine and that knowing smile he gets when he's up to something. How did the birth a shift go, he asked. Already pouring two glasses. Terrible. Giovanni fired me. His grin widened. Perfect timing. What do you mean perfect timing? I just lost my job. We have a mortgage, Scott bills. He pulled out his laptop, fingers dancing across the key board. Remember that food critic from the times who came in last month, Julia Chen, the one who wrote that amazing review about your lamb dish? Yeah, of course. She said it was transcendent. Why? Well, Scott said, turning the screen toward me, she's been discreetly asking around town about hiring a private chef for her daughter's wedding next weekend. Very exclusive, very high paying. I may have already told her you'd be available. I stared at the email thread. Julia had been trying to reach me for weeks, but Giovanni never passed along messages. She was offering $15,000 for a single event, more than I made in three months at Romano's. Scott, how did you my phone Buzz text message, then another. Then it started ringing. Giovanni's number flashed on the screen. I let it go to voicemail. Then more calls. The assistant manager, the sous chef, even the dishwasher. By the time I checked, there were 47 missed calls. And count. Scott was refreshing his laptop cackling, oh, this is beautiful. Look, a skating review had just gone live on every major food blog and review site, posted an hour ago, right around when Giovanni would have been running dinner service without me. Romano's Restaurant, a spectacular fall from Grace, read the headline. The review was brutal. Food quality has completely.

What would you do if your parents charged you $5 for smiling and $10 for laughing since you were 4 years old? That was my reality. By 17, they claimed I owed them $300,000 in joy debt. They had color coded spreadsheets packing every smile, every laugh, every moment of happiness I'd stolen from them. Since I could walk, I Learned to keep my face blank, stone cold nothing. They said I was stealing their peace by being happy. So they'd actually Bill other families when I smiled around their kids $25 for infectious Joy contamination. They call my childhood became a financial transaction. Giggling at a cartoon, that's $15. Smiling at a dog, another $5. They had categories for everything. Spontaneous laughter was $20, but if they deemed it excessive, it jumped to $40. Birthday parties were banned because they called them joy festivals that would bankrupt me. I ate lunch alone in bathroom stalls because sitting with friends meant potential joy charges if someone told a joke. I slept on the floor in my room because my mattress was collateral for unpaid happiness debts. They pulled me from art class, music class, any elective that might spark joy because college isn't for debtors anyway. The worst part, they made me sign contracts, actual legal looking documents, promising to pay them back with interest once I turned 18. They'd already picked out my future jobs, three minimum wage positions to maximize debt repayment speed. They even calculated compound interest Rates and projected pay off dates through 2055. My neighbors knew about the system. Some thought they were genius parents who'd solve the spoiled child problem. Others would cross the street when they saw me coming, afraid of being charged for any accidental happiness I might display. The mailman started avoiding eye contact after they build him $30 for making me smile with his dog videos. They had a special punishment room in the basement where I'd sit for hours reciting my debt total. The walls were covered with financial charts showing exactly how much my emotions had cost them over the years. They'd invite relatives over just to show off their innovative parenting system and watch me demonstrate my perfect emotional control. But they made one huge mistake that changed everything. During a meeting to officially withdraw me from school, they brought their ledgers, all of them 13 years worth of documentation. They were so incredibly proud of their innovative parenting system

My fiance said, I'll sign the prenup when hell freezes over. I said, fair enough, and quietly canceled our 85,000 dollar wedding. Her face went pale when she got the cancellation notice. I'm watching my ex fiance Bianca blow up my phone right now. She just found out I canceled our entire wedding that was supposed to happen in 4 months. See, I own a tech consulting firm that's done pretty well. Not yacht money, but comfortable. She's an influencer making maybe 30 k a year. When we got engaged last year after dating for 3 years, she immediately went into wedding planning overdrive. Not just any wedding. Her dream wedding. Historic 8 venue for $15,000, catering for 250 guests at $30,000, flowers for $8,000, photographer and videographer for $10,000. Her dress for $12,000, band for $6,000. The list kept going. Total damage $85,000. I was fine with it initially. I loved her, wanted her happy, had the money saved. But then my lawyer friend Garrett pulled me aside at a barbecue. Yo, you getting a prenup? Haven't thought about it. Dude, you own a business. You need one. If she's cool, no harm done. So I brought it up that night casually. Hey, Garrett mentioned we should probably do a prenup. Standard stuff for business owners. The temperature in the room dropped in. You think I'm a gold digger? Bianca snapped. No, it's just standard legal Protection. If you loved me, you'd trust me. I do trust you. This Is just. I'll sign a prenup when hell freezes over. Bianca, be reasonable. You be reasonable. We're supposed to be partners. What's yours is ours, but what's mine is. Well, you know, I don't have money like you. Don't be ridiculous. God, why are you being so cheap? She stormed off. I figured she needed time to cool down. Nope. Next day, she told her whole family I was financially abusing her by asking for a prenup. Her mom Deedee, called, screaming, how dare you insult my daughter like this? I asked for a standard prenup. That's not an insult. She's giving you the best years of her life. She's 28, not 80. And I'm giving her mine, too. A real man doesn't need contracts with his wife. Click. She hung up on me. Bianca came back that evening, acting like nothing happened. Started showing me centerpiece options. We need to resolve the prenup thing first. I said there's nothing to resolve. I'm not signing it now. Roses or peonies? Bianca, I'm serious. So am I. Drop it or there won't be a wedding. Okay, good. So, peonies? Sure. Whatever you want.

What made the girl's girl turn her back on every girl who needed her? We all knew Holly would let the world burn if it meant keeping girls safe. She literally treated female friendship like a sacred religion. She'd walk wasted girls home from parties, share her last tampon with girls she'd never met, and somehow knew which guys to avoid before anyone else did. Every girl had her number saved for emergencies because they could all count on her to fix things. There was this one time at lunch when the football players were ranking girls by their bodies out loud. Holly walked right up to their table, took photos of all of them, and announced she post them on the school's parent Facebook age with exactly what they've been saying unless they apologize to every single girl individually. That was Holly's whole identity. She lived for female solidarity. She'd stay up all night talking girls through breakups, pretend to be someone's girlfriend to get creeps to back off, fight with teachers who dress coded girls unfairly. During junior year, when the cheerleaders started that toxic diet competition, Holly brought homemade cookies every day until they stopped weighing themselves. The girls would cry on her shoulder, trust her with their darkest secrets, and she treat protecting them like her life's purpose. Then winter break passed, and Holly showed up wearing headphones, staring at her phone, completely ignoring the circle of girls who'd been waiting to tell her their break Drama when Neva ran up crying about her boyfriend cheating, Holly literally stopped around her and kept walking. She didn't hold the door for the freshman girl carrying too many books. Didn't smile back at anyone. During lunch, Amira was sobbing about her parents'divorce, and Holly would have normally dropped everything to comfort her, but she sat alone the entire time. The worst part was when Sienna fainted in the hallway from not eating. Old Holly would have been the first one there. This. Holly glanced over, watch the nurse handle it, and went back to her homework. Girls kept approaching her all day. Summer needed a tampon. Holly shrugged and said she didn't have one. Freya asked for a ride home because she felt unsafe. Holly said, call Uber without looking up. We all thought she was going through something heavy, maybe seasonal depression, maybe family problems. Some girls organized an intervention. They cornered her after school with flowers and her favorite coffee. Hallie took one look at them and said, I'm not interested. Just that. Then walked to her car. Days turned into weeks. The girls went from concerned to desperate. They made a schedule to check on her, left notes in her locker, even got the counselor involved. Hallie told the counselor she was focusing on herself and there was nothing wrong. When that didn't work, they told one of our teachers. She asked Hallie why she wasn't helping organize the Women's Empowerment Orman Assembly. Halle responded, That's not my responsibility anymore. Then we all found out what happened. During a massive New Year's Eve party at Wyatt's house. Halle had gone with her closest friends, prepared to be designated driver and protect anyone. But then someone spiked her drink, and she started feeling really sick and disoriented. She'd managed to lock herself in an upstairs bathroom when she realized something was seriously wrong. Holly had texted the group chat with her friends, the ones she called her soul sisters. She typed, please help. Something's wrong. I think someone put something in my drink. I'm scared. I locked myself in Wyatt's bathroom. Please come get me now. Then another. I can't stand up properly. Please hurry, then.
NA
NA
NA

video_description: I moved out when my PARENTS...  #shorts#reddit #reddit_tiktok #redditreadings #askreddit #fyp #foryoupage #redditstorytime #Reddit #fypage #shortstory
voice_to_text: I moved out when my parents asked me to pay rent. So I'm 23, oldest of five kids, and basically running my parents house like I'm the damn manager or something. I'm in school full time getting my second degree, plus I work part time in my field. My employer already said they'll take me full time once I graduate, so I'm making decent money for a student. Enough to pay for school and actually save some cash. My siblings are 20, 17, 14, and 10. My parents both work. Dad pulls crazy long hours and mom does the 9 to 5 grind at some stressful job. So guess who picks up all the slack? Me. I do literally everything. Grocery shopping every week, all the laundry for seven people, cooking dinner every single night, and meal prep on Sunday so everyone has lunches ready. I even manage my siblings chores like making sure there's dog food in the pantry so my youngest brother can actually feed our two dogs. Or that we have poop bags on the leashes. It's like being a mom to four other people. Plus going to school during Christmas break. I finally had enough saved up to buy myself a PS five. Been wanting one forever and I found one at regular price. But if you know anything about PS Fives in 2022 was basically winning the lottery. The rest of my family still shares this old PS four in the living room, but I Keep mine in my room. It's mine, I bought it. And no, I don't share it. Well, my 20 year old brother Jake started whining to my parents about how unfair it was that I had all this money and cool stuff but wouldn't share. Like, dude, get a job, but whatever. So my parents call me into the kitchen for this family meeting, which was basically them telling me I need to start paying rent. They said it wasn't fair that I was making good money while living there for free. Especially when I won't even share my gaming console. I just sat there listening to them explain how much they wanted from me monthly. And I'm doing the math in my head. After rent, I'd have maybe $800 left over each month. That's after buying my own food, gas, school supplies, everything. I went to my room and actually calculated it out on paper. If I dropped a couple classes next semester, I could go almost full time at work. It would only add one more year to my degree, but I could afford my own place. And here's the kicker. I'd actually have more free time and way more spending money than if I stayed home paying rent while doing everyone's chores. So I packed up my stuff. Everything I owned fit in my Honda Civic, which honestly was kind of depressing, but also liberating. I didn't tell them I was leaving until I was loading my Car, where are you going? My mom asked, standing in the driveway in her bathrobe. Getting my own place. Thanks for helping me realize I can afford it. I stayed at this Airbnb for two weeks while I figured out apartments, adjusted my class schedule, and got more hours at work. The Airbnb host, this older lady named Beverly, kept asking if I was okay because I was just so happy to be there. Like, I was literally excited to do my own laundry. And. Okay, I'm not gonna lie. I went a little crazy on dating apps. Living at home with 4 siblings and strict parents meant I hadn't had any.

My husband shook me awake and asked, why do you stand at Mary's doorway for hours every night holding kitchen knives? I jerked upright in bed, heart pounding against my ribs. What are you talking about? I don't do that. He held up his phone screen, glowing in the darkness of our bedroom. I have it on video, Julia. Every single night I watched myself on the hallway camera footage, standing perfectly still at our six year old daughter's door. Two kitchen knives clutched in my hands, one in each fist. The time stamp read 12:03 a m. That's not possible, I whispered. But there I was, motionless for hours. According to the fast forward layback, miles scrolled through multiple recordings from the past week. Same position, same knives, same bacon expression on my face. I had absolutely no memory of any of it. How long has this been happening? I asked, my voice cracking. Miles pulled up the footage history on his phone. I installed the camera a month ago when Mary mentioned hearing footsteps. Thought maybe she was sleepwalking. He showed me night after night of recordings. You stand there from midnight until almost 4:00am. Then you just walk back to bed. We reviewed more footage together. Sitting at the kitchen table with his laptop, I appeared at eleven fifty eight PM in every video. Retrieved the knives from the kitchen drawer and took my position like clockwork. Miles had dark circles under his eyes. I hadn't noticed. Before, I didn't want to scare you, but this isn't normal. Julia. We need to get you help. Have you asked Mary about this? I managed to ask. He nodded slowly. She says she hears tapping on her window sometimes. I checked outside, but never found anything. My blood turned cold. Tapping on her window. I instinctively stood up and walked to the knife drawer, pulling it open. The two largest knives were at the front, handles facing out. Had I arranged them that way? That night, I forced myself to stay awake. Miles set up his phone to record me, and I sat on the couch drinking coffee. At 11:45 p m, a strange heaviness washed over me. I fought against it, digging my nails into my palms. The I hit 11:00am and everything went black. I woke up at 407:00am, standing in our bedroom, miles staring at me with wide eyes. You just stood there again. I tried to talk to you, even shook you, but you were completely gone. He showed me the new footage. I looked like a statue. Unblinking, unmoving. Except for the subtle rise and fall of my chest. The next morning, I examined Mary's window from outside. Small scratches marked the frame, concentrated around the lock. Fresh marks overlapped older ones. My hands trembled as I took photos. Miles called the police while I questioned Mary. Tell me about the tapping sounds, sweetheart. She looked up from her coloring book. They stopped. A While ago. Now I just hear you walking around outside my door. Officer McCoy arrived within the hour and exam in the window. These are tool marks. Probably from someone trying to Jimmy the lock. She photographed everything meticulously. Has anyone been watching your house? Any strange vehicles? We couldn't think of anything unusual. She recommended motion sensors for the backyard and extra locks on Mary's window. Miles installed cameras outside that afternoon. If someone's been trying to get in, we'll catch them. That night, he stayed awake to monitor all the feeds while I inevitably blacked out. He kissed my forehead at 11:45 p m. Maybe your subconscious knows something we don't. At 12:47 a m, according to Miles's frantic retelling the next morning, a figure appeared at Mary's window. Dark clothing, face obscured by a hood. It produced a thin metal tool and worked at the lock while I stood guard inside. Knives ready. The figure tried for 20 minutes before giving up and disappearing into the shadows. Miles had called 9 1 1 immediately, but the intruder vanished before police arrived. Officer McCoy reviewed the footage with us. The build looks familiar. Height about 5 feet, 10 inches. The way they moved. She paused the video. Do you recognize anything? That's when it clicked. Light hunch of the shoulders. The way they favored their left hand. Oh, my god. That's Isaac, our babysitter's boyfriend. The police moved fast. They arrested Isaac that morning at our babysitter's apartment. The search warrant revealed the worst possible outcome his lap

video_description: My parents told me, you're adopted, you get nothing when we die. Then grandma's lawyer called.#reddit#reddit_tiktok#redditreadings#askreddit#fyp#foryoupage#redditstorytime#Reddit#fypage#shortstory
voice_to_text: My parents told me you're adopted. You get nothing when we die. Then Grandma's lawyer called. The call came while I was eating cereal before my shift at the auto parts store. Austin called. Well, this is Margaret Stevens, state attorney. Your grandmother, Eleanor, left you something. I almost laughed. There's been a mistake. My parents said I wasn't in her will. Mr Caldwell, we need to meet immediately. Two hours later, I'm staring at documents, $2.1 million a house, investment accounts all mine. But I'm adopted, I stammered. Margaret handed me a letter in Grandma's handwriting. Austin, you are not adopted. You're my biological grandson. Your father's first wife, Jennifer, was your real mother. She died when you were 2. Susan made David pretend you were adopted because she wanted you gone. My hand shook. 21 years of being treated like garbage while my siblings got cars and vacations. I work two jobs just to afford ramen. Every family dinner where they discuss college funds for Logan and Ashley. But when I asked about help with community college, dad would say you need to learn independence. Letter continued, David and Susan think they're inheriting everything. They've been spending money they don't have. The new truck, kitchen, remodel, Logan's boat they borrowed against my estate. They get nothing. But there was more. Margaret pulled out another folder. Your grandmother hired a private investigator three years ago. She documented everything. Photos of me walking to work in the rain because my bike Broke screenshots of my parents social media posts bragging about their inheritance windfall while I lived on peanut butter sandwiches. Messages between Susan and her friends. Can't wait for the old bat to die so we can finally live properly. The investigator had recorded conversations too. Susan's voice came through crystal clear. Austin thinks he's family, but he's just David's mistake from his first marriage. Once Eleanor's gone, we'll have enough money to cut them off completely. Your grandmother was furious. Margaret said she changed her will six months ago. Your parents get nothing. Your siblings get $1,000 each. Everything else goes to you. The best part, the investigator had proof they'd already spent $200,000. They didn't have new credit cards, loans against their expected inheritance, deposits on a vacation home in Florida. I drove to their house with Margaret. It was Friday night, their weekly family dinner that I was never invited to. Through the window, I could see them celebrating with champagne and expensive takeout. Susan opened the door, saw us both, and her face lit up with greed. Finally, Margaret right. How much did mother leave us? We've been waiting so patiently. Logan and Ashley crowded behind her, practically bouncing with excitement. David appeared with a bottle of champagne, ready to toast their good fortune. I smiled. Actually. She left me everything and this letter explaining how you lied about me being adopted. Susan's face went white. That's impossible. You're not even real family. Oh, but I Am I pulled out the birth certificate get grandma had kept safe. My mother was Jennifer Caldwell, you know, Dad's first wife, the one you made him pretend never existed. David's champagne bottle slipped from his hands, shattering on their expensive marble floor, the floor they'd renovated with money they thought they'd inherit. This has to be a mistake, Ashley whispered. Margaret stepped forward. There's no mistake. Austin inherits two point one million dollars, the house and all investment accounts. You three children each receive $1,000. David and Susan receive nothing. Nothing. Susan's voice cracked. But we borrowed, we spent, oh, about that $200,000 you borrowed expecting your inheritance. I held up the legal paper. The bank wants it back tomorrow with interest. Logan started crying. But my boat payments, the vacation, house deposit, not my problem. I said. Maybe you should have treated your brother better. David finally found his voice. Austin, please, we can work this out. We're family. No, I said, looking him dead in the eye. Jennifer was family. Grandma, Eleanor was family. You're just the people who made my life hell for 21 years. Margaret handed them the official paper, papers you have 30 days to vacate any property belonging to the estate. Austin is the sole heir. As we walked away, I could hear Susan screaming at David, Ashley sobbing about her college fund being gone, and Logan frantically calling someone about returning his boat. Justice tastes sweeter than any inheritance money ever could. The house keys felt perfect in my hand.

video_description: My neighbor asked why I mow my lawn with scissors at 4 AM every Sunday. #reddit#reddit_tiktok#redditreadings#askreddit#fyp#foryoupage#redditstorytime#Reddit#fypage#shortstory
voice_to_text: My neighbor knocked on my door and asked, why do you mow your lawn with Scissors at 4:00am every Sunday? I stared at Missus Peterson through my screen door, coffee mug frozen halfway to my lips. I don't mow my lawn with Scissors. That's insane. She shifted uncomfortably on my front porch, clutching her robe tighter against the morning chill. Well, someone does. Every Sunday at exactly 4 in the morning, I hear this snip snip snip sound coming from your yard. It wakes up my whole house. I glanced past her toward my front lawn, which looked perfectly normal. Green, well maintained, clearly cut with a regular mower, like every other yard on open Drive. Missus Peterson, I use a gas mower on Saturday afternoons. You've seen me do it dozens of times. Her expression shifted from annoyed to confused as she followed my gaze to the obviously machine cut grass. But the sound is definitely coming from your property. My husband heard it, too. What exactly does it sound like? I asked, stepping outside in my pajamas to get a better view of my yard. Missus Peterson made a cutting motion with her fingers, like someone trimming hedges, but rhythmic snip snip snip for hours. I walked around to my backyard, with her following close behind, both of us scanning for anything unusual. That's when I saw them. Tiny, perfect circles cut into the grass near my back fence, each about six inches in diameter, not random patches. But precise geometric patterns carved into the lawn with surgical precision. Missus Peterson, I didn't do this. My voice came out smaller than intended. The circles formed a complex design that would have taken hours to create with Scissors. And I've been found asleep every Sunday at 4:00am for the past month. I pulled out my phone and took photos of each circle, documenting the strange pattern while Mrs. Peterson watched nervously. The cuts were too clean for animals, too precise for lawn equipment, too deliberate for vandalism. Someone had been accessing my backyard weekly to create these designs while I slept. Have you seen anyone in my yard? I asked, but she shook her head. Her bedroom window faced the front of my house, not the back. I walked to my rear gate and found what I was looking for. Fresh scratches around the lock mechanism, tiny metal shavings on the ground. Evidence someone had been picking the lock repeatedly. My stomach dropped as I realized a stranger had been entering my property for weeks without my knowledge. Missus Peterson, I need to check something inside. I ran to my security system panel and pulled up the motion detector logs. Every Sunday for the past six weeks, the backyard sensor had triggered at exactly 3:00am, then again around 7:00am. But I dismissed these as false alarms from neighborhood cats. I scrolled through the digital records, finding the same pattern week after week. Someone had been studying my routine, waiting For me to fall into deep sleep before beginning their mysterious lawn art project. The precision of the timing suggested they knew my schedule better than I did. I called the police while Mrs. Peterson waited in my kitchen, both of us staring out the window at those perfect circles. Officer Bradley arrived within twenty minutes and examined the evidence with growing concern. This level of precision suggests obsessive behavior, he said. Photographing the circles and the damaged gate lock. Someone's been planning this for weeks, possibly months. He pointed to older scratches around the lock that I'd never noticed. These marks go back further than six weeks. This person's been accessing your property much longer than the lawn cutting. I felt violated in a way I couldn't articulate. Someone had been treating my home as their personal art studio while I slept defenseless inside. The officer recommended changing all my locks immediately and installing motion activated cameras throughout the backyard. Two weeks later, my new security cameras captured everything. Exactly 3:00am on Sunday, a figure in dark clothing climbed over my back fence and began the meticulous process of cutting grass with small scratching Scissors. But when I reviewed the footage in daylight, zooming in on the person's face, my world tilted completely. It was my ex boyfriend, Nathan, who had broken up with eight months ago after discovering he'd been secretly filming me in my own bathroom. The same Nathan who'd sworn he'd leave me alone after I Threatened a restraining order. The same Nathan who apparently still had a key to my back gate and when we dated, and had been using it to continue violating my space in increasingly elaborate ways. The circles weren't random art. When I printed out photos of all the patterns and arranged them chronologically, they spelled out words. Mine in the first week, forever in the second, watching in the third. Nathan had been leaving me messages in my own lawn, counting on my Assumption that the noise was just. Neighborhood maintenance Officer Bradley arrested Nathan the following Sunday as he climbed over my fence with his Scissors and a flashlight. The investigation revealed he'd been documenting his visits with photos, keeping a detailed journal of my daily routines, and planning to escalate to breaking into my house. Nathan got 18 months in jail for stalking and trespassing. I got new locks, better security cameras, and the knowledge that someone cutting grass at 4:00am is never just about lawn care.

When did my house, my rules become please don't put me in a shelter? Growing up, my dad had one phrase that he loved. My house, my rules. When I was 16 and wanted to dye my hair purple for junior year, he stood in the bath from doorway, blocking my path. Not under my roof, Alexis. You want purple hair, get your own place. When my boyfriend asked me to prom, dad made him sit through a two hour interrogation before declaring, no dating until you're 18. My house, my rules. I couldn't even watch PG thirteen movies until I was 17 because inappropriate content isn't welcome under my roof. My friends stopped coming over after dad made them sign a behavioral contract to enter our home. He controlled what I wore. No ripped jeans in my house. You look homeless. What I ate vegetarian phase. Not at my dinner table. And my opinions, too. You don't get to disagree with me while you're living rent free. When I got accepted to art school, he laughed. Art degree? Not with my money. You'll study business or nothing. Mom would whisper apologies when he wasn't looking, but never stood up to him. The worst part was his favourite closing line whenever I protested. When you have your own place, you can do whatever you want. Don't like it? There's the door. He'd literally point to the front door, knowing I had nowhere to go. At 17 with eight. Two dollars, In my savings account. Life isn't fair, Princess. The person who pays the bills makes the rules. Remember that. Well, I took student loans and went to art school anyway, living in a studio apartment with three roommates and a family of roaches. Dad called it learning life the hard way. Should have listened to me about that business degree, he'd say during Sunday dinners, while I was building my graphic design portfolio at 3 a m. Dad was getting comfortable in early retirement at 55, spending his days watching Fox News and calling me to criticize my lifestyle choices. Still living in that dump, he'd ask. Still single because you're too picky? Still wasting time on those computer drawings? His words hurt, but I kept going. Meanwhile, his perfect life started cracking. Mom finally left him after 30 years, tired of the controlling behavior. She's going through menopause, he told everyone, refusing to admit she'd simply had enough. Then his health declined, and he got diabetes. From decades of my house, my beer choices. He even refused to take his medications properly, because no doctor tells me what to do in my own home. Next, his house started falling apart, with a roof leaking and the foundation cracking. But he was too proud to ask for help. And too cheap to hire anyone. I built this house. I'll maintain it my way. By the time I landed my senior design director position, making six figures at 29, Dad was 67, living alone in a deteriorating house, alienated from most family members and struggling with basic tasks, but still preaching about his rules whenever anyone would listen. Then one day, my phone rang and his name popped up. Alexis. How's my successful daughter? Red Flag already? He never spoke that nicely. What do you need, dad? Can't a father call his daughter? You only call when you want something. Long pause. The house is getting to be too much. Your mother used to handle things, but now she's gone. I was thinking maybe I could stay with you for a while. I knew this was coming. He'd been posting on Facebook about his struggles, fishing for sympathy. But I wasn't going to just refuse because I had a secret plan. So I told him, of course you can stay with me. Dad. I have a

What made the girl's girl turn her back on every girl who needed her? We all knew Holly would let the world burn if it meant keeping girls safe. She literally treated female friendship like a sacred religion. She'd walk wasted girls home from parties, share her last tampon with girls she'd never met, and somehow knew which guys to avoid before anyone else did. Every girl had her number saved for emergencies because they could all count on her to fix things. There was this one time at lunch when the football players were ranking girls by their bodies out loud. Holly walked right up to their table, took photos of all of them, and announced she post them on the school's parent Facebook age with exactly what they've been saying unless they apologize to every single girl individually. That was Holly's whole identity. She lived for female solidarity. She'd stay up all night talking girls through breakups, pretend to be someone's girlfriend to get creeps to back off, fight with teachers who dress coded girls unfairly. During junior year, when the cheerleaders started that toxic diet competition, Holly brought homemade cookies every day until they stopped weighing themselves. The girls would cry on her shoulder, trust her with their darkest secrets, and she treat protecting them like her life's purpose. Then winter break passed, and Holly showed up wearing headphones, staring at her phone, completely ignoring the circle of girls who'd been waiting to tell her their break Drama when Neva ran up crying about her boyfriend cheating, Holly literally stopped around her and kept walking. She didn't hold the door for the freshman girl carrying too many books. Didn't smile back at anyone. During lunch, Amira was sobbing about her parents'divorce, and Holly would have normally dropped everything to comfort her, but she sat alone the entire time. The worst part was when Sienna fainted in the hallway from not eating. Old Holly would have been the first one there. This. Holly glanced over, watch the nurse handle it, and went back to her homework. Girls kept approaching her all day. Summer needed a tampon. Holly shrugged and said she didn't have one. Freya asked for a ride home because she felt unsafe. Holly said, call Uber without looking up. We all thought she was going through something heavy, maybe seasonal depression, maybe family problems. Some girls organized an intervention. They cornered her after school with flowers and her favorite coffee. Hallie took one look at them and said, I'm not interested. Just that. Then walked to her car. Days turned into weeks. The girls went from concerned to desperate. They made a schedule to check on her, left notes in her locker, even got the counselor involved. Hallie told the counselor she was focusing on herself and there was nothing wrong. When that didn't work, they told one of our teachers. She asked Hallie why she wasn't helping organize the Women's Empowerment Orman Assembly. Halle responded, That's not my responsibility anymore. Then we all found out what happened. During a massive New Year's Eve party at Wyatt's house. Halle had gone with her closest friends, prepared to be designated driver and protect anyone. But then someone spiked her drink, and she started feeling really sick and disoriented. She'd managed to lock herself in an upstairs bath through when she realized something was seriously wrong. Holly had texted the group chat with her friends, the ones she called her soul sisters. She typed, please help. Something's wrong. I think someone
