Am I the only one who doesn't think the 67 meme is funny? Like, bro, everywhere I look, it's just 67 this, 67 that. People spamming it in comments, plastering it all over TikTok. And I'm sitting here like, what's so special about a number? Like the way people are obsessed? You'd think 67 cured cancer or unlock GTA 6 early. But nah, it's literally just two digits. I'll open my group chat, 67. I load up a game. Someone's username is 67. She's following me around like a bad dream. And the wild part is people act like if you don't laugh at it, something's wrong with you. Nah, bro. Maybe it's just not funny. The internet takes the most random thing and runs it into the ground until you can't escape it. Get out.

Guys, it's official. On my word, we are now bringing back the low taper fade meme from the grave. Like, I don't care what the internet says. This is the comeback of the century. After my rant about the 67 meme, I don't wanna hear a single 67 in my comments. If you even think about typing it, I'm pulling out the banhammer straight up. You're gone. From this point on, it's only low taper fade comments allowed. I wanna see it everywhere. Spam it, make it the new anthem. If 67 can take over the whole internet, then low taper fade deserves its time to shine again. So, yeah, the 67 era is dead. We're closing the chapter. The future is low taper fade. And if you're not with us, you're against us. Get out.

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like, at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly, someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket. Just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet, using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight, but by 12:30, half of them are knocked out through, and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation? Wild. You got 10 people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custom battle. Someone's sneaking chips at 4:00am, and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. When morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock, and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part? Parents roll in like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.

Okay, but like if there was a real fire in school, we are 100% not surviving. The alarm goes off, right? And instead of running or panicking like normal people, we start walking at 2 miles an hour single file in total silence. Like, bro, are we evacuating or lining up for picture day? No talking, no urgency, just everyone slowly shuffling like, hmm, yes, let's casually escape the flames. Meanwhile, the fire is probably in the hallway doing a speed run and teachers are like, let's stay calm. I am calm. I'm just also trying not to become a rotisserie chicken. One kid brought their lunch box, another brought nothing, and someone's asking if they can go back for their iPad. We are done for. If we're treating a fire like a library trip, we're toast, literally.

The school called saying my daughter was dealing pills in the parking lot. I checked my daughter Kate's bank account and saw zeros where $300 should have been. Kate was 16 and worked 20 hours a week at a burger place, but somehow her entire paycheck had vanished. When Kate got home from her shift, I confronted her with the statement, I've been buying stuff for Zoe at school. She has a baby and nobody helps her, she explained. My first thought was that someone was running a sob story scam on my naive daughter, but Kate insisted that Zoe desperately needed help and the baby would suffer without it. The next morning, I gave Kate extra cash and told her to give it to Zoe. Thanks, Mom. Zoe's going to cry when I give her this. That afternoon, I got a call from the school. We need to discuss something serious with you about Kate. Immediately. I rushed to the school, expecting the worst. Your daughter was seen in the parking lot giving another student prescription bottles and cash and what appeared to be a substance deal. We have zero tolerance for substances on school property, and we've already contacted the school resource officer. He turned his computer screen toward me to show the security footage of Kate handing we two orange prescription bottles and money by her car. I felt sick realizing I've been giving Kate money that might have been funding prescription substance stealing. Mr. Hayes said Kate claimed the prescriptions were antibiotics and diaper cream for a baby, but that sounded like a ridiculous lie to cover up selling pills. No teenager carries around multiple prescriptions for a baby they don't have, he said while shaking his head. That's when the school nurse walked in carrying a baby who was caught so hard his tiny body shook with each breath. This is Zoe's son, she said quietly while patting his back. She brought him to my office this morning because he ran out of his breathing medicine and she didn't know what else to do. The principal went completely silent. The nurse explained that Zoe was 16 and had been trying to finish school while raising a six month month old baby alone. Her parents had kicked her out and she'd been living in her car for the past month. The prescriptions Kate gave her were antibiotics for the baby's lung infection and prescription diaper cream for an infected diaper rash that had gotten so bad it was bleeding. Kate had been using her own money to buy them because Zoe couldn't afford the copays. I was proud of my daughter, but also heartbroken. No teenage girl should be living in a car with a sick baby. I told Mr. Hayes I wanted to keep helping Zoe and asked where I could find her. He said she usually stayed in the parking lot after school until security made her leave. After school we found Zoe in The parking lot, trying to change her baby's diaper in the backseat of her car. She saw us coming and immediately started to panic like she was going to drive away. But Kate ran over before she could start the car. It's okay. This is my mom. She wants to help. Please don't call anyone. They'll take him away, and he's all I have left. Zoe begged through the cracked window. The baby was wheezing so loud I could hear it from outside the car, and his little face looked gray. I convinced her to let me sit in the passenger seat so we could talk. She explained that they had been living in this car for over a month, and she washed the baby in gas station sinks at night when nobody was around. I asked about the baby's father and watched her whole body start shaking. His name is Nathan. His dad teaches chemistry here at school, she said so quietly I could barely hear her. I was 15 when Nathan invited me to his college party. He was 21 and kept giving me drinks until I couldn't stand up straight. Then he rocked me. A few weeks later, when I told Nathan I was pregnant, he laughed in my face and said nobody would ever believe trash like me over him since he's premed at the university. She started sobbing and told us that his dad had cornered her after class one day. He grabbed my arm. So hard it left bruises and said, listen, you whore, if you ever mention my son's name in connection with that bastard baby, I will personally make sure you fail every single class and never graduate. I sat there feeling pure rage build in my chest as this child described being threatened and abandoned by adults who should have protected her. As a lawyer, I knew exactly what these monsters had done wrong and how to make them pay for it. I told Zoe she was moving in with us. That night, we packed everything she owned into trash bags and drove them to our house. I set up a crib in the guest room while Zoe took her first hot shower in two months and cried the entire time. The next morning, I filed for emergency child support and demanded a court ordered paternity test. I also reported Nathan to the police for statutory rape. Nathan tried to dodge the test for three weeks by claiming he didn't even know Zoe until the judge threatened to have him arrested when the DNA results came back proving he was the father. The judge was furious that a 21 year old had impregnated a 15 year old and then abandoned his sick child. The court ordered Nathan to pay $28,000 in back support immediately. The District Attorney filed felony statutory RP charges that would require him to register as a sex offender under for life. His dad also got fired. A Week after I reported his threats to the school board, three months later, Zoe was back on track to graduate with her class, and her baby was happy and healthy for the first time in months.
NA

My family was planning to order takeout and asked my sister's kids what they wanted. As my kids waited their turn, my mother coldly said, your kids can eat whatever scraps are left in the kitchen. They're not guests here. My sister smirked, and don't forget, I'm staying all week, so you're covering my meals, too, my dad added. Now go set the table. Like a good little servant, I stayed quiet, took my kids to a fancy steakhouse instead and made one phone call. Hours later, they were calling me in panic. It was supposed to be a regular weekend family dinner, nothing fancy, just take out, laughter, maybe a movie. After my parents invited my sister and her kids to stay the week. And naturally, I was expected to come help out like usual. Ever since my divorce, I've kept to myself, but I still tried to maintain some family connection for the sake of my kids. So when it came time to order dinner, everyone was gathered in the living room. My sister's two kids immediately shouted out what they wanted, pad Thai, dumplings and Boba from their favorite spot. My kids waited patiently like they always do. They were next in line, literally. But my mom didn't even glance at them. She snapped, your kids can eat whatever scraps are left in the kitchen. They're not guests here. I looked at her, thought maybe I misheard, but nope. She turned to me, hands on hips, and Added, we already have too many mouths to feed. You know how tight things are right now. Then my sister, smug as always, said, and don't forget I'm staying all week so you're covering my meals too. I blinked. She said it like it was a royal decree. And as if that wasn't enough, my dad, who'd been mostly quiet, barked from the kitchen, now go set the table. Like a good little servant, servant. My kids looked at me, one of them whispered, Mommy, can we just go home? I didn't yell, I didn't cry. I just calmly stood up, grabbed my purse, called my kids over and said, let's go out for dinner. We didn't go to a cheap burger joint. We went to the nicest steakhouse in town, the kind where they bring the drinks on a silver tray and call your kids sir and ma'am. My kids sat wide eyed as waiters pull their chairs out and handed them mini menus. I posted a photo of our dinner, steaks, mocktails, lava cake in the family group chat. No caption, just the picture. But that wasn't a big move. As my kids savored dessert, I made one call, just one, to someone I knew would flip their perfect little dinner world upside down. And a few hours later, my phone exploded with calls from my family, voicemails, texts, missed Facetimes, all of them saying the same thing. What did you do? Let me rewind a bit so You understand the weight of that one phone call. I don't just have a job, I have leverage. For the last six years, I've been quietly helping my parents manage their finances behind the scenes. After my dad's failed retirement investment, they nearly lost the house. I stepped in, used my credit, refinanced in my name and saved it from foreclosure. They never told anyone, especially not my sister. In return, all I asked was respect, not groveling, not grand gestures, just respect and for my kids to be treated like human beings. Clearly, that was too much. The person I called during dessert, my banker, the same one who helped me set up a contingency clause in the mortgage paperwork. The house was saved under my name, but the deal was if certain conditions were breached, namely verbal or emotional abuse of me or my children, I had the option to freeze the financial support and trigger a re evaluation clause with 30 days notice. That clause activated immediately. But I didn't stop there. Before the steakhouse check even hit the table, I logged into the Shared Utilities portal and cancelled my auto pay. That $437 monthly electric Bill, that $220 gas Bill, gone for my account. I also sent a brief email to my parents, HOA, for legal instruction. Please direct all correspondence regarding fees or violations to the property owners only. I am withdrawing from all communication as of today. That triggered a domino effect. None of Them saw coming. By the time my family got home, Belly's full of Thai takeout, probably still laughing about me setting the table like a good little servant. They walked into a house with a blinking red light on the thermostat. My dad must have checked the smart panel because the first voicemail I got said, what the hell is going on? The thermostats blinking. Some warning. We called the electric company and they said the accounts been flagged for pending disconnect because the last payment bounced and no backup method is listed. I thought you had this handled. Then one for my mom. We're not getting hot water. What are you doing? Is this some childish tantrum? And finally, one for my sister, the cherry on top. Seriously, you're sabotaging your own parents because you didn't get to pick dinner? Grow up. You're a bitter, useless drama queen. She had no idea. She had no idea that for the last five months I'd also been paying for the insurance on her car. Not out of generosity, but because it was bundled into a plan that gave me a massive corporate discount, which I just ended. They wanted to treat me like I was disposable. Cool. But now the invisible safety net they've been using to live above their means snapped and I wasn't done yet. The voicemails were one thing, but the panic spilled into the public eye faster than even I expected. The next morning I woke up To six missed calls, a dozen texts, and surprisingly, a Facebook post from my mother that read, some people are so heartless after all we've done for them, they choose to ruin their own family over something petty. We may not have hot water right now, but at least we still have each other. Shame on those who turn their back when we need the most. Translation, she was trying to rally sympathy. Classic tactic, playing the victim for attention. But then my cousin, bless her chaotic, neutral soul, commented, wait, didn't she save your house like 2 years ago? And hasn't she been paying your bills? You told me she was the reason you could still afford groceries. What happened? The thread blew up. A few other family members, ones who'd always quietly noticed the favoritism, started chiming in. One posted a screenshot from months ago of my mom gushing about the miracle of their mortgage being handled and how god sent help just in time. The dots were connecting fast. People were doing the math.

Every school has that annoying ass girl group who thinks they're the shit and every boy likes them. Like bro, they're always looking for attention. Like, Omg, everyone is staring at us. Yeah, we're staring because you sound like three fucking malfunction car alarms fighting each other. And then one of them says the most fucking driest, corniest and unfunniest ass joke I've ever heard in my time of living and they all start laughing like a dying pack of hyenas choking on sand. What the fuck? And then my fuck ass friends have the audacity to say, you like her, don't you? Like what? No, they're all fucking chopped and built like oversized vending machine. They have new boyfriends every week like it's a fucking Netflix series. New season, new guy. They make fun of other people looks, but then they take pictures and scribble out the spots on their face like, bro, you're just a fucking hypocrite. The worst part is when the girl everyone thinks I like starts playing along with it. So that just makes it even more fucking believable that I like her. I always explain to everyone that no, I don't fucking like her. She sounds like a dying vacuum cleaner choking on Legos that went up its ass. But no, I still continue. At this point I might as well just confess to my real crush so people stop shipping me with that ugly hippo. Anyway, have a great fuck ass day.

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favourite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there. Always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends. I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person, while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.
NA

I told my boyfriend that his masculinity was fragile after he refused to buy me pads. My boyfriend Ethan and I had been dating for two years when this whole thing started. We lived in this tiny apartment together and split everything pretty evenly. He'd grab groceries, I'd cook dinner. Normal couple stuff. But there was always this weird thing where he'd get uncomfortable about anything period related. Like if I left a tampon wrapper visible in the bathroom trash, he'd make this face like I'd left a dead rat there. If I mentioned cramps, he'd immediately change the subject or leave the room. I thought it was just typical guy awkwardness and figured he'd grow out of it. Then last month happened. I was at work when my period started early, which sucked because I had nothing with me. I texted Ethan asking if he could grab some pads from the store since he was already out running errands. Usually went to the grocery store on Wednesdays anyway. His response was immediate. Can't you just get them on your way home? I explained that I was stuck at work for another four hours and really needed them now. I even told him exactly which brand and where they were in the store. He lived at that grocery store. He knew where everything was. Ask one of your co workers, he texted back. I was confused. My co workers were all middle aged men who worked in construction. We were The only company in this tiny office building. I told him this, and his next message made my blood boil. I'm not comfortable buying that stuff. It's embarrassing. I stared at my phone for, like, five minutes. This grown man, who had no problem buying condoms, beer, or even my weird stomach medicine when I had food poisoning, was too embarrassed to buy period products for his girlfriend of two years. I called him Ethan, I literally cannot leave work. I'm bleeding through my clothes. Just ask someone to cover for you or something. There's no one here to cover for me. You're being ridiculous. That's when he got defensive. I'm not being ridiculous. I just don't want to be that guy in the store buying tampons. People will stare. Who cares if people stare? And I need ads, not tampons. Same thing. Look, can we talk about this later? I'm busy. He hung up on me. I ended up having to call my friend Jess, who drove 20 minutes out of her way during her lunch break to bring me supplies. She was furious when I told her what happened. When I got home that night, Ethan was playing video games like nothing had happened.

Fucked around. The finding out was biblical. I show up to practice Thursday night at the regular time, and my three bandmates are sitting in a circle without their instruments, like they're about to hold an intervention. Lead singer says we need to talk about the band's future. Battle of bands is in 10 days, and apparently we need to level up our image. That's when I noticed the drummer's girlfriend standing in the corner holding a bass. My bass, actually, that I let him borrow last week. She's holding it upside down. Lead singer looks at me. Look, you're great and all, but she has the look we need. She's been learning bass for, like, two months. Two months? I've been carrying this band for three years. But sure, let's get the girl who thinks the bass has six strings. They vote 3 to 1 to replace me. Right there with me, watching like I'm getting voted off a reality show. The guitarist, who still can't play an F chord cleanly, actually says, it's nothing personal. Nobody's looking at the bassist anyway. Might as well have someone pretty back there. Nobody's looking at the bassist. I wrote half our songs, but okay, Brad, tell me more about how music works. The drummer's girlfriend tries to be nice. You can still come to the show if you want to support us. Support them? Sure. Let me buy a ticket to watch you play my bass badly. Sounds like a dream. Friday night. I don't argue, don't yell. Just say okay if that's what you all want. The lead singer seems surprised I'm not fighting back. Probably expected tears. Sorry to disappoint. They're already talking about keeping the band name and the set list for battle of bands. Acting like everything's normal. Planning tomorrow's practice like I was never even there. Like I'm already a ghost. Guitarist mentions they'll see me around and I just nod, give them a smile that doesn't reach my eyes, walk out quietly. I can hear them talking about stage positions as the door closes. She'll look great in the back. How the judges will love having something nice to look at. They think this is over. They think I'm just going to crawl away and cry. That's cute. I'm sitting in my car in the driveway and my brain starts doing math. Tomorrow's practice. They kept saying see you at practice tomorrow to each other. But wait, that's my amp the guitarist uses because his sounds like a dying cat. My mixing board that makes our lead singer not sound like he's singing through a kazoo. The mic system I bought with birthday money. The cables, the stands, hell, even the extension cords are mine. I check the battle of bands registration on my phone. The song list they submitted Breaking Chains I wrote that. Midnight Drive wrote that in my bedroom. Phoenix Rising that's literally about my ex boyfriend. I have the notebooks with The original lyrics in my handwriting. The van we use for gigs. Mine. Well, technically my mom's, but she lets me use it. And then it hits me. This is my dad's garage. Dad only lets them practice here because of me. I text him, hey, the band just kicked me out for not being pretty enough. He text back immediately. Are you kidding me? They're banned. I'll change the garage code right now. My dad's the best. They kept saying, see you at practice tomorrow. They actually think they're still practicing here tomorrow. In my dad's garage, with my equipment, playing my songs. The delusion is actually impressive. Next day, five PM, I'm home.

Shawarma was barely known in the US until Iron Man made it famous. Shawarma quietly arrived in the US back in the 1970s with Middle Eastern immigrants. But for decades, barely anyone outside the Arab community knew what it was. That all changed in 2,012 when Marvel released the Avengers. During the final battle, Iron Man casually mentioned shawarma, an off script moment that wasn't even in the original screenplay. Marvel doubled down and filmed a post credit scene showing the Avengers silently eating shawarma in a half destroyed restaurant. And somehow that awkward scene made shawarma go viral. Searches for what is shawarma exploded. Americans flooded shawarma shops and a food that had spent decades in the background suddenly went mainstream, all because Iron Man got hungry.

Why don't homeless people just try and rob a bank? Like hear me out. If they're successful, they're instantly rich. No more sleeping under bridges. They're straight up balling. But if they fail, what happens? Jail, which is basically free food, free bed, free shelter, free Wi-Fi if you're lucky. That's literally a win win situation, bro. Worst case scenario, you end up with three meals a day and a roommate named Big Mike. Best case scenario, you're the next Elon Musk, but without the lawsuit. Honestly, I don't get why no one's speed running this strategy. It sounds more efficient than half the self improvement TikToks I see.

My mom had that same glowing look she gets every couple years. And my dad was bouncing on his heels like an excited puppy. We have amazing news, my mom announced, putting her hand on her stomach. You're all going to be big brothers and sisters again. My siblings started jumping around and scream, I mean with excitement because they don't understand what this actually means. More chaos, less attention. And guess who's going to be stuck changing diapers and doing midnight feedings again? Me. I didn't even wait for them to finish their little announcement speech. I walked straight to my room, grabbed my phone and called my grandparents. My hands were literally shaking as I dialed their number. Grandma, it's me. Mom's pregnant again and I can't do this anymore. Can I please come live with you guys, like today? There was silence for about 10 seconds. Then I heard my grandma take a deep breath. She's what? Another one? Those two have lost their minds. Pack your things, sweetie. Grandpa's already getting the car keys. I threw all my important stuff into two duffle bags, clothes, my laptop, chargers, and most importantly, my passport and birth certificate from my parents filing cabinet. I Learned that trick from Reddit. Always grab your documents first. My parents were still in the living room explaining to my siblings how exciting this was going to be. When I walked past with my bags, my dad looked confused. Where are you going? With those grandma and grandpa's permanently. My mom's face went white. What do you mean permanently? You can't just leave. Watch me. That's when they both started freaking out. My dad blocked the front door and started this whole lecture about family responsibility and how they needed my help now more than ever. My mom was crying, saying I was being selfish and dramatic. But I was done listening to their guilt trips when my grandparents knocked on the door 20 minutes later. I pushed past my dad and didn't look back. Now my parents are absolutely losing their minds because they realize they actually have to parent their own kids. They've called the cops on my grandparents twice, claiming I was kidnapped or whatever. The cops took one look at the situation, saw that I'm 17.
NA

My whole family cut me off because my cousin said I got her pregnant. But now the truth came out. I was 22, just started my dream job as a mechanic, when my phone exploded with hate messages. My 16 year old cousin Sarah told everyone I've been sneaking into her room and got her pregnant. Nobody asked for my side. My mom screamed through tears that I was disgusting, asking how she raised such a monster. Dad just hung up on me. My sister Emma blocked me on everything without a word. Even my grandmother, who practically raised me after my parents divorced, hung up crying, saying she was too ashamed to talk to me. Sarah was the family Princess. Straight A's, honor roll, church youth group bleeder. Every Sunday. I was the high school dropout. Within 24 hours, the whole extended family had turned against me. My aunt posted these long Facebook rants about protecting our children from creeps hiding in our own family. My uncles were leaving voicemails, threatening to beat the hell out of me if they ever saw me again. Cousins I grew up with were sharing screenshots of our old photos with comments like, can't believe I trusted this creep. I waited every single day for police to show up with handcuffs. Every knock on my door made my heart stop. Every unknown phone number sent me into panic attacks, thinking it was detectives or lawyers. I lost everything, piece by piece. My job, At the auto shop because I couldn't focus. Kept making stupid mistakes, showing up late, calling in sick. My boss, Mike, finally sat me down after three months and said whatever was happening at home needed to stay there. But I was too broken to explain. Lost my apartment four months later when I couldn't make rent. Moved in with my buddy Jake. Let me crash on his couch. But even Jake started asking weird questions when family never visited or called. Dude, where's your family? It's been six months, and I've never seen in a single relative. I made up lies about them living far away, being busy, having drama. Dating became impossible. How do you explain why your entire family disowned you? First girl I tried seeing asked to meet my parents after two months. I panicked and told her they passed in a car accident. She was so sympathetic, it made me sick. Second girl saw through everything. When she noticed I had zero family photos in my apartment, no one to invite to anything. She asked Point Blank why I never talked about my family. When I couldn't give her a straight answer, she was gone by morning. Holidays destroyed me completely. Everyone else had somewhere to go, someone to call, someone who cared they existed. I drive past my old neighborhood and see all the cars in my parents'driveway, knowing they were all inside, laughing and eating together without me. I finally moved three states away. To Colorado and started completely over. New job at a different auto shop, new apartment, new friends who knew nothing about my past. For years, I lived like I had no family. Like I just appeared out of nowhere as an adult. Never dated seriously, because I couldn't risk anyone digging too deep into my background. Built walls so high, I forgot what it felt like to trust anyone. Then last month, my phone rang at 11 p m. Unknown Colorado number. Which was weird, because nobody had the

What happened when you dated someone out of your league? Victoria cornered me after bio and slid $500 across the lab table. I need you to be my boyfriend for three weeks, she whispered. Didn't even know why she was talking to me. Victoria drove a white Mercedes to school. I took the bus. When she saw how confused I was, she finally explained, my 18th birthday is in eight months. That's when I'll get access to my trust fund. She leaned in closer, but I want it now. And if I'm dating someone inappropriate, then they'll probably offer me some deal to dump you. They always think cash fixes everything. She said it like a joke, like her parents trying to buy her off was funny. So you in? I stared at the money. $500. That's two months of groceries. When do I start? She smiled, different from her usual popular girl smile. Tomorrow I'll pick you up at 7 for dinner at my house. Then she walked out, leaving me with five bills and no idea what I just agreed to. First time at her house, I thought I was being pranked. The driveway went on forever. They had a fountain with actual koi fish. I counted six cars, all different brands. Her parents were in the formal living room. Mom, Dad. This is Dakota. Her mom's smile died. Her dad's eyebrows went up. Hey, up my boyfriend, Victoria added, grabbing my hand. Her palm was sweaty. Yo, Her dad cleared his throat. And what do your parents do, Dakota? Straight to the job question. My mom's a nurse, I said. Didn't mention the second job, cleaning offices. Didn't mention my dad hadn't been around since I was 10. Her mom's smile got tighter. How nice. After that disaster, Victoria set up our routine. Pick me up every morning, hand holding between classes. We need to be seen together, she said. Make it believable. She even made me an Instagram so she could tag me in stuff. But something shifted the second week. She started doing this thing where she'd play with my fingers while we talked, probably for show, but it felt real. We went to this party at her friend's house, mansion, obviously, pool the size of a lake. She stayed by my side all night, introduced me to everyone proudly. This is Dakota, she'd say, like I was someone special, not just the hired help. When some douchebag made a comment about me shopping at target, she shut him down hard. At least Dakota works for his money, she said. What do you do besides spend daddy's cash? The guy had nothing to say. That's when her phone buzzed. My parents saw us this morning, she whispered, showing me the text. They're furious. Her soft hand grabbed mine. Let's go somewhere quieter. We ended up on this balcony overlooking the city. Lights everywhere like stars, but on the ground. She was wearing this dress, blue Probably cost more than my mom's rent, but she made it look easy, normal three months till my birthday, she said random. She turned to me close, really close. Dakota, I need to tell you something. My heart did this weird skip thing. This was it. She was gonna say this was more than just fake, that somewhere in all the pretending it became real like it had for me. What I, I asked. She bit her lip, looked away, then back. My parents want to meet with us tomorrow, both of us. Oh, they said they have a proposal about my trust fund. I bit my tongue so hard it tasted like copper. The meeting was at their house formal dining room. This time felt like a court hearing. Her parents sat on one side us on the other, papers between us, actual printed papers. Dakota, her dad started, you see?
NA
NA

When did you just barely avoid jail? My friends always used to say I had the most generic looking face in our city. You're like the default character in a video game. They joke, and honestly, they weren't wrong. Everywhere I went in Cleveland, people swore they knew me. Hey, don't you work at the grocery store on 55th? Weren't you at my cousin's wedding? It was funny at first. Until it wasn't. One morning, I was working the register at the hardware store when two cops walked in. I figured they were just grabbing supply until they asked my name. The next thing I knew, they spun me around, cuffed me, and started reading me my rights. My co workers froze, customer stared, and I just kept saying, this has to be a mistake. They dragged me out anyway, like I've been caught red handed. At the station, they pulled up the security footage of a gas station robbery from a week earlier. My stomach dropped. The guy on the screen looked exactly like me. Same build, same beard, same haircut. Even the same black hoodie I wore all the time. I almost convinced myself it was me. It got worse. Three different eyewitnesses picked me out of a lineup, no hesitation. That's him, 100%. I didn't even have an alibi that night. I've been home gaming, not texting or calling anyone. No receipts, nothing. To the cops, I was their guy. The evidence stacked up so neatly against Me, it felt unreal. My public defender sat me down and gave it to me straight. With video, eyewitnesses and no alibi, you're looking at serious time. The DA is offering a plea deal. Two years if you plead guilty. If you fight it and lose, you could get 10. I thought about it. Two years for something I didn't do. 10 years if I lost. My chest felt like it was caving in. But I couldn't do it. I couldn't sign a piece of paper saying I was guilty when I wasn't. So I tried something else. I got my hands on the footage and posted it online.

My brother told my mom about my search history, so I turned him into a fanboy and removed his virginity. Look, don't come for me until you've heard the full story. My little brother Liam decided to be a hero. Went through my phone, found my search history, you know, the usual stuff, anime, memes, some specific art like fanboys, furry as and other stuff. Instead of being a bro, he printed it, highlighted it, gave our mom a full Powerpoint presentation at dinner. I was grounded for a month. Mom looked at me like I drowned a puppy. I didn't scream. I didn't fight him. That's what he wanted. I got creative. Liam's a gym bro. All he cares about are his games and his loser football friends. His biggest fear, being perceived as soft or cute. So I became his personal stylist against his will. Phase 1, I swapped his manly body wash for my lavender and honey scrub. Within a week, his teammates were asking why he smelled like a bath and body works. The confusion on his face was priceless. Phase 2, Laundry warfare. I started mixing my clothes with his. A lace trim from my fishnets tangled in his jeans. A revealing top snuck into his load. His gray sweats came out smelling like vanilla and shimmering under the lights. The masterpiece was the school charity event. I bought two dozen rainbow bracelets, paid his best friend 20 bucks to tell everyone Liam had a Crush on some goth boy by the bleachers and was changing his vibe to impress him. Overnight, the narrative shifted. Liam wasn't just a jock. He was the sensitive king. His friends thought it was hilarious. They dared him to wear a choker, bought him a skirt as a joke. And the thing is, he didn't hate it. The attention was an addiction. He started asking me for advice, how to walk in platforms, how to do eyeliner. His search history quickly became way worse than mine. He started a TikTok pretty boy Liam. But I wasn't done. I introduced him to my friend Alex. Alex is persuasive. They started talking, hanging out. Then one night, I heard things from his room. Let's just say Alex fully educated him, clapped his cheeks. Now, Liam doesn't just dress the part. He lives it full time. He never apologized for snitching. He probably doesn't even remember these days. He's too busy picking out fishnets and living his best life. So yeah, I got revenge. I didn't just change his clothes. I changed his entire life. And honestly, he's never been happier. You're welcome, Liam. Maybe now mom will finally stop looking at me.

My husband slept through every feeding until my sister said she fantasizes about leaving you. He finally woke up. My husband made me promise we would keep things normal after the baby was born because he read online that babies need to adapt to your life, not the other way around. I agreed because I was 9 months pregnant and too tired to argue about his parenting theories from Reddit. The second we got home from the hospital with our 3 day old daughter, he disappeared into his gaming room. I stood in the hallway holding our screaming baby while he told his online friends he was finally back. I spent the first three months doing every single night feeding while he slept peacefully in our bed. He actually bought special noise cancelling headphones so the crying wouldn't disturb his precious 8 hours of sleep. You look like you're about to drop dead, my sis, Mr Mindy, said when she showed up at my front door. I hadn't seen her since the baby shower because she lived six hours away. When was the last time you ate actual food or slept more than an hour? She dropped her bags and immediately took the baby baby from my shaking arms. You have lost at least 20 pounds and your hands won't stop trembling. She pulled me into the first real hug I had gotten since giving birth. I didn't realize how much I needed a hug. Where is your husband? I Pointed down the hall where he was screaming about someone stealing his kill. Mindy listened for a second, then her whole face changed completely. You have been doing this alone while he plays video games all day, haven't you? Before I could answer, she said, go shower right now while I watch the baby. Then we are going to talk about whatever this mess. She started washing the mountain of bottles that had been sitting for days. You are not doing another night alone while that waste of space pretends you don't exist. I stood under the hot water and cried harder than when I was in labor. When I came back downstairs, Mindy had the baby sleeping. Pee. You look exhausted, she said. Actually looking at my face. When's the last time someone asked how you're doing? I couldn't remember. My husband hadn't asked since we left the hospital three months ago. He'd asked if the baby was fed, if she napped, but never once. How are you holding up? Your husband games every night until 4:00am, Mindy asked, looking at his empty gaming chair. My ex did that. I ended up hospitalized from exhaustion. He didn't visit. That hit hard. Even strangers at the grocery store asked how I was doing, but not him. I came back downstairs from my shower and stopped in the hallway when I heard voices in the kitchen. My husband had actually left his gaming room and was talking to Mindy who was Still feeding our daughter. We don't need any help, he was saying with obvious irritation in his voice. Everything's been fine here without you showing up and judging how we do things. Mindy kept calmly feeding the baby while she responded. Fine. Your wife has lost 20 pounds and hasn't slept in three months. I watched him grab an energy drink from the fridge and crack it open aggressively. She wanted a baby so badly and now she complains about everything he said. Maybe if she wasn't so dramatic about normal mom stuff, we wouldn't have issues. And he finally looked up at him with cold eyes. Normal mom stuff? She told me she thinks about leaving you. His hand froze halfway to his mouth with the energy drink. She fantasizes about packing up and disappearing because raising a baby alone.

Neighborhood crackhead lunged at me so I turned him into a femboy and sold him on Etsy. I live in a sketchy little neighborhood where everyone minds their business except for this one dude. Let's call him Rico. Rico is, well, he's like a local cryptid. No one knows where he lives but he appears at 3:00am yelling about government conspiracies, anime girls and how he once fought a raccoon with his bare hands. Classic Rico. Anyway, last night I'm walking back from the corner store with a bag of Hot Cheetos and chocolate milk living my best trashy life when out of nowhere Rico lunges at me like a feral possum in heat. He's screaming something about me stealing his aura. At this point my fight or flight kicked in and apparently my brain chose black magic. See, I've been dabbling in some alternative arts lately. Long story short, I had a transformation Hex saved on my notes app. Don't ask why, just accept it. So mid lunch I screamed the words, clap my hands together and suddenly poof, Rico is no longer Rico. Rico is now Rianna. Pink crop top, cat ears, thigh high socks, eyeliner sharper than my credit score, the full Femboy starter pack. He blinks, I blink. We both stand there for a solid five seconds like, did that just happen? Fast forward to today and uh, I may have listed him on Etsy under Handcrafted Chaos Beings. Someone from Portland bought him within 3 Minutes for 275 plus shipping. Now I'm sitting here sipping my chocolate milk, trying to process the fact that I may have invented a new side hustle. Before anyone asks, yes, Rico. Now Rianna is thriving. The buyer sent me pics. He's got a maid outfit. Now I don't know how to feel.

Just because we don't talk anymore doesn't mean that I've forgotten about you. It doesn't mean that I no longer care, because the truth is, I still do. I find myself doing my best to check up on you, to see how you're doing, to see if you're okay. But every time I get the urge to talk to you, it suddenly hits me that we're strangers now, that you don't want me in your life, hence the reason why I'm no longer part of you. Even though everything's changed, I want you to know that I'm still here. I'll still be here for you. I'll still lend you my shoulders and my ears. And I don't care what time it is. I don't care what I'm doing because half the time I wish that you were talking to me. I just really miss your presence. I miss you being my best friend. I just miss you in general. No matter the circumstances, my feelings for you haven't wavered. If you ever need someone to talk to or lean on, I'm here. Time may have created a distance, but my care for you remains constant. Wishing you all the best.

What rule in your house would horrify other people? We had a rule in our house. If dad was wearing his red baseball cap indoors, nobody was allowed to talk to him. Not a word. Not even pass the salt at dinner. It wasn't every day. Maybe once or twice a week, he'd come home from work, red cap on, and we'd all just navigate around him. Mom would put his dinner plate down silently. My sister and I would do homework in our rooms. If we needed something from the living room and he was there, we'd wait. I thought this was totally normal. Like how some dads have a don't bother me during the game rule. Ours was just the red cap thing. Friends were over and saw the cap. I'd whisper, Red Cap Day, and they just shrug, and we'd play outside. The rule was so ingrained that I once got in trouble at school for ignoring a substitute teacher. She was wearing a red hat, and my brain just went, don't talk. I couldn't even explain it properly to the principal. Mom enforced it hard, too. my little sister asked dad for help with homework on a red cap day. Mom grabbed her arm so tight it left marks and dragged her to a room. Later, she apologized, but said we had to respect Dad's needs. In high school, I finally asked mom why dad needed red cap days. She got this tired look and Said your father works very hard, and sometimes he needs quiet to decompress. The cap helps us know when to give him space. Made sense to me. Dad's work hard, whatever. I moved out for college, and roommates thought it was hilarious when I'd warn them about my dad's red cap rule. Before this, it's just don't talk to him. If he's wearing it, he's cool otherwise. Last year, I'm home for Thanksgiving. I'm 26 now. Dad's wearing the red cap at dinner. We're all eating silent when my boyfriend, who I'd warned repeatedly, accidentally says, sir, could you pass the Turkey? The entire table freezes. Dad's hand stops halfway to his fork, his jaw clenches. Then he just get it's up and leaves. Doesn't say a word, just walks out to the garage. Mom starts crying. Actually crying at Thanksgiving dinner. My boyfriend is mortified, apologizing profusely. I'm pissed at him, but also confused by Mom's reaction. It's just the stupid cap rule. Why is she sobbing? My sister pulls me aside later. You really don't get it, do you? Turns out dad wasn't decompressing. The red cap days were when he was.

My school tried deleting my YouTube channel, so now I'm exposing them. After I exposed my bullies on YouTube, I thought it was strange that my principal wanted to delete my channel instead of punishing the bullies, but I just discovered what the school is really hiding. You see, I knew there had to be some reason the principal was siding with the bullies. It makes no sense to punish me for just making a video talking about my horrible experience. The girls had literally gotten away with no punishment. But apparently, I'm not allowed to upload anymore. So I did some digging onto the school website, hoping there might be something that connected the principals with those girls. I looked around for hours, and at first I found nothing. I honestly didn't even know what I was looking for. But eventually, I finally realized the truth behind his actions. I click onto the donor's page, and at the very top, I see a face that looks really familiar. But when I see the name, that's when it hits me. This was the mother of my school bully. And the principal had just been trying to keep his top donor happy this entire time by excusing her daughter for the bullying. Think I'm gonna let this slide? Nah. I'm exposing my school to the whole world. Help boost the video by subscribing.
NA

Have you ever noticed that the school bathroom during class just stops being a bathroom? You walk in expecting silence, maybe a cough, maybe the faint smell of lemon cleaner. Instead, it's a fully operational underground economy. First of all, there's a kid leaning against the wall like a mob boss selling individual skittles for 50 cents. He's got a little ziploc bag of them and this tiny notebook where he writes down who owes him money. Like, bro, what happens if I don't pay you? Are you gonna send the urinal guys after me? Second stall, the doors locked, feet dangling, kids not using the bathroom. Nope, they're sitting on the toilet lid like it's a lounge chair playing Clash Royale on full volume. And when you glance under the stall, they shush you like you're interrupting a performance. By the sinks, there's three kids treating it like a mirror photo shoot. They've got sunglasses, LED lights. One kid's holding a ring light. Where did they get a ring light? We've been in school for two hours. I don't even think the janitor has a ring light. Then you got the acrobats. Some 7th grader decides the handicap stall is now a gymnast Astics Arena, and they're doing pull UPS on the stall door frame while their friend times them with a stopwatch. Meanwhile, the door is creaking like it's seconds away from ending someone's bathroom career. And through all this, the only person actually using the bathroom is A mystery kid. They're always in the last stall, always completely silent. And somehow they've been in there since second period. So now I'm just standing there holding my hall pass, trying to wash my hands without getting roped into buying a two dollar Starbucks or accident only joining a TikTok dance. And when I leave, the teacher's like, you were gone for 10 minutes. What were you doing? Ma'am? I just survived an entire bathroom circuit. I think I deserve extra credit.
NA

Why do we all have that one friend whose parents are insanely strict? Like, we'll all plan to meet up at my house, and he has to run it by his parents. Like, he's testifying in court, I'll text him, yo, wanna grab food? And he's like, hold on, let me check. First 10 minutes go by, nothing. 30 minutes, still no word. Then an hour later, he finally replies like, yeah, I can't go. My mom said I didn't vacuum the stairs last week. Like, bro, do you live in a house or a prison? And on the rare occasion he actually gets permission, it's like he's got on an ankle monitor 24 7. He has to text his mom when he leaves, when he arrives every 30 minutes. Like, we'll be mid conversation and suddenly he's like, hold on, my mom needs proof I'm alive. Bro, we're at the movies watching Superman. He's the one fighting villains, not us. But the worst part, this guy's got a curfew that would make an eight year old cry. He's gotta be home by 8:30 sharp or he's grounded until the next presidential election. One time we were literally five minutes late dropping him off, and his parents acted like we just smuggled him across state lines. His mom's at the door grilling us like she's an FBI agent. Did he drink alcohol? Did he get arrested? What did he do? Bro, we went to Taco Bell. The most dangerous thing he Did was spill Baja blast on his hoodie

Why does school make the dumbest rules and act like they make sense? Like you can't wear a hoodie. It's a safety hazard. Okay, so is my GPA. But here we are. They'll say no hats or hoods. We need to see your face. For what? So you can watch me slowly lose the will to live in real time. And don't forget the classic no phones in class. Meanwhile, the teacher is literally texting while telling me not to. Or how about you can't eat in class? I'm sorry, I've been awake since 6:00am running on two hours of sleep and a dream. And now I'm banned from goldfish crackers. Everything's a distraction except for the flickering lights, broken clocks, and Kevin's weekly tantrum. Like, seriously, y'all are enforcing hoodie laws while the ceiling is leaking? Like, and subscribe.

Why do we all have that one friend that can never be serious? I could be telling them about my dog that got flattened by a train and bro will genuinely just burst out into laughter like he was watching the greatest stand up special in the world. I swear I could tell them I have six weeks to live. And bro will just be like, we really got bro passing away before GTA 6. One time me and bro were at a funeral and right as they were lowering the casket, you just hear in the faint distance like, bro, why are you playing Clash Royale at a burial? And the worst part is that he doesn't even see anything wrong with it. Like he'll just shrug and be like, what? I'm coping. Like, bro, how is hitting a 3 crown on ladder your emotional support?

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favourite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.

Why is it when a teacher asks a question and nobody answers, the room suddenly turns into The Hunger Games the second she goes, anyone wanna try? Dead silence. Not a cough, not a shuffle, just pure fear in the air. Everyone suddenly forgets how to function. Nobody moves, nobody breathes. We all look down like we just saw the secrets of the universe in our empty ass notebooks. And then she says it. The dreaded line, alright, I'll pick someone. That's when the real panic sets in. I'm looking down like my shoelaces just became the most interesting thing I've ever seen. People are flipping through blank notebooks like, hmm, yes, fascinating equations I'm not actually reading. And the teacher, she starts scanning the room like a hawk with a sniper scope. You make one wrong move, blink too loud, shift in your seat. Boom! Then she locks eyes with you for half a second and goes you, why don't you give it a go? Bruh, I didn't even make eye contact. I was breathing. Respectfully. This isn't fair! I was just trying to survive. And when they finally call someone, the rest of us sit there like survivors of a near death experience. PTSD from a math problem.

We all got that one classmate, the class snitch, the teacher's pet, but like the cursed version. He's the guy who raises his hand mid chaos like, miss, they're not doing their work, bro. Neither are you. You just wanna be seen. Everyone's just trying to vibe and do the worksheet in peace. And here he comes. Um, actually they have gum. Okay, what do you want? A badge? He crashes out of group work every time, but still somehow reports us like he's in the FBI. Bruh, they didn't let me speak. You spoke for 15 minutes about Minecraft. Oh, hell no, man. And what makes it worse, he thinks all the teachers love him. Walks around like he runs the school. Me and Mr Johnson are basically best friends. Meanwhile, Mr Johnson sighs when he walks in. Even the nice teachers fake a smile when he raises his hand. Nobody invites him to the group chat. Nobody partners with him. But somehow he still thinks he's the main character.

My sister in law used my expensive skincare products for her wedding but didn't tell me until after the photos came out. I've had a horrible adult acne since college, like the kind where people ask if you've tried washing your face. As if I haven't spent thousands of dollars trying everything. Finally found a dermatologist who put me on this intense prescription routine, tretinoin, clindamycin, gel, the works. Cost me $300 a month, even with insurance. But it was worth it because my skin finally cleared up. My sister in law, Emma was staying with us for two weeks before her wedding. She kept asking about my skincare routine, touching her own face and sighing. I told her it was mostly diet changes and patience, plus regular dermatologist visits. She wasn't buying it, though. She'd follow me to the bathroom and peek at my medicine cabinet while I brushed my teeth. One morning I caught her reading the labels on my prescription bottles. I told, told her those were serious medications and my dermatologist specifically warned me never to share them. She just laughed and said she was curious. Emma has always been the type to borrow clothes without asking, so I should have seen this coming. The night before her wedding, she was freaking out about a tiny pimple on her chin. I offered her some of my gentle face wash, but she said it wasn't strong enough. I went to bed around 11, exhausted from helping with Last minute wedding stuff. The wedding was beautiful. Emma looked absolutely radiant in all the photos. Her skin was literally glowing better than I'd ever seen it. Everyone kept commenting on how perfect her complexion was. Even the photographer mentioned it. I felt genuinely happy for her. Two days later, she posted on Instagram with this long caption, thanking god and a miracle product for her wedding day glow. She tagged the location as our house and wrote about discovering the most amazing skincare routine. My stomach dropped. I checked my medicine cabinet immediately. My tretinoin tube was.
NA

You know what's crazy? Tomorrow, September 5th, at 107:00am, 67 minutes into the day, we will be 67.67% done with 2025. Like, what? Did 6 7 actually have a meaning the whole time? Like, this coincidence is so crazy that I'm about to wake up and see everyone on social media and people at school talk about 6 7. About to hear, see, touch, feel, and taste 6 7. Matter of fact, I'm about to live 6 7. 6 7 has gotten to the point where it's a literal god point. Just make September 5th a holiday for 6 7.

Bro, I just realized something and it's kind of messing with my head. Okay, listen, s is the 19th letter in the alphabet. I is the 9th, X is the 24th. Add that up, 19 + 9 + 24 = 52. Now 5 + 2 = 7. Cool, that's our 7th. Now take the word devil. D is the fourth letter, E is the fifth, V is the 22nd, I is the ninth, and L is the twelfth. 4 + 5 + 22 + 9 + 12 = 52 again, and 5 + 2 is 7. Again, two different words, same number. Now here's where it gets weird. Look at the month we're in right now, September. That's the ninth month. Flip that 9 upside down and you get 6. Put that next to the 7 we just found, 6, 7. It's literally everywhere. Random words, random numbers, they all somehow line up to 6 to 7. I don't even know what this means, but it definitely feels like a warning from the universe.

Why is it actually terrifying when you're at your friend's house and they tell their mom you're hungry? Like, great, now she thinks I pulled up to run a 5 star GTA heist on her pantry. Like the other day I'm hanging at my friend's place after school, but dude has the appetite of a hummingbird, one granola bar and he's full. And I don't wanna ask for food at his house. I want him to offer like a normal human. So I start dropping hints. A McDonald's commercial comes on and I'm like, dang, a Mcchicken would go crazy right now. Then I get up to grab a glass of water and stare into the fridge like I'm touring an art museum. I even ask, yo, do you guys ever do pizza rolls here or. Nah. He just shrugs and says, I'm not really hungry. Oh, didn't ask about you. But then, and when he finally picks up on the hint, instead of having his mom make us a snack, he just leans toward the kitchen and yells, mom dog is hungry. Can you make him something? Like, bro, why would you say it like that? Now she either thinks my parents don't feed me at home or I'm a big back here to clear out her fridge. Yeah, do I secretly want to inhale all the food in their house? Yes, but that's beside the point. Subscribe.

What would I do if I had Infinite Roblox? Easy. Absolutely ruin the Roblox economy in less than 24 hours. First thing, I'm buying every single limited on the market. All of them. You want that Domino's? Too bad I bought it. I bought your friend's copy, and I bought the entire catalog just because I can. Then I start handing them out like oh, you get a Valkyrie helm! You get a Valkyrie helm! Everybody gets a Valkyrie helm! Trading community would collapse overnight, and I'd be sitting there laughing in my new virtual mansion made entirely of Roblox. Next, I troll every game. Imagine joining Brookhaven and tipping the pizza delivery guy 10 million robux just for bringing me one slice. Or jumping into Pet Simulator X and dropping so much robux that the game physically breaks trying to process. Developers would worship me like a god. And don't even get me started on avatars. My character would change outfits every two seconds. Golden suits, diamond drip, entire outfits made of cash. Basically I'd be the Elon Musk of Roblox. Except instead of rockets, I'm launching myself into every server and flexing until the game crashes.

2015 should be considered Gen Z. 2018 should be considered Gen Z. Clearly, a lot of people don't know what generations are. So let me explain it. Generations are simply based on the year you were born. Gen Z is 1997 to 2,012. It doesn't matter if you think you had a Gen Z childhood or you relate more to people in Gen Z. And I think a lot of kids are embarrassed to be a part of Gen Alpha, but it is completely normal for older generations to make fun of younger generations. And a lot of the kids saying that they had a Gen Z childhood didn't really have one at all. For example, I saw a kid saying 2015 should be considered Gen Z because they liked fidgets when they were younger and lived through Covid. I don't know about you guys, but most of Gen Z grew up on squishies and slime. And considering that they would have only been 5 to 6 years old during Covid, like how would they even really experience how Covid was like considering the era of it on TikTok and stuff? And just because you don't make skippity toilet jokes doesn't make you Gen Z anyways. I hope these kids learn to just accept it. By the way, this.
NA
NA

I kicked my family off my Amazon plan. So my whole family had been using my Amazon Prime account for like three years. My mom, my sister Ashley, my Uncle Rick, even my grandma somehow figured out how to order stuff. I was paying for it because I actually use Amazon all the time for work stuff and groceries. But they were just leeching off it. The breaking point happened two weeks ago. I check my account and see 17 packages coming to different addresses, 17. My sister ordered a whole workout set she'll never use. My mom got some fancy face cream that cost 60 bucks. And my uncle Rick ordered a drone he definitely doesn't need. But the worst part was my cousin Blake ordered a gaming chair that cost $400. I called Blake and asked him what the hell he was thinking. He just laughed and said it's not his problem. I gave everyone access. He said if I didn't want people using it, I shouldn't have shared the password. This kid just graduated high school and acts like he runs the world. So I called my mom and told her everyone needed to chip in for prime or get their own accounts. She got all dramatic and said family should help each other out. She reminded me how she used to buy me clothes when I was younger. I told her that was literally her job as a parent and not the same thing at all. Then Ashley calls me crying, saying she can't afford her own prime account because she's saving for a wedding. I reminded her that her wedding is in two years and she just spent $300 on workout clothes she turned last month. She said I was being petty and that it's only like $10 a month split between everyone. I did the math. If everyone chipped in 10 bucks, that would actually cover prime and give me extra money. But when I suggested this in our family group chat, suddenly everyone had excuses. My mom said she's on a fixed income. Ashley said she's saving for the wedding. Rick said he barely uses it anyway, which is a lie because he ordered protein powder just yesterday. The final straw was when my grandma called me confused about why her soap order got cancelled. Turns out my account got flagged for suspicious activity because there were so many different addresses, Amazon temporarily locked my account and I couldn't order my medic.

What happened when you dated someone out of your league? Phoebe walked up to me at my grocery store job and said, I need you to pretend to be my abusive ex. I dropped the can of soup I was stocking. Phoebe Kang, valedictorian, going to Harvard in the fall. Perfect grades, perfect life, perfect everything. What the hell? How was she doing? Talking to me? My actual ex won't leave me alone, she explained, glancing around nervously. He keeps showing up at my house, my work, everywhere. But he's 6 4 and on the foot all team. She pointed to herself. I'm 5 2, and my parents think I should just handle it diplomatically. They don't understand that Austin's not taking no for an answer. So where do I come in? You're bigger than him. If he thinks I'm with someone who could actually fight back, maybe he'll back off. I've seen you loading trucks in the parking lot. You're not exactly small. I look down at myself. Yeah, I was bigger. Worked construction summer since I was 16. Built like my dad before he took off. What's in it for me? I'll help you pass calculus. You're failing, right? I've seen your test scores posted outside Morrison's classroom. She wasn't wrong. I needed that credit to graduate. Mom was already stressed enough without me not walking across that stage. Fine. But we do this my way. What do you mean? We're not pretending you're with some psycho. We're Showing him you're with someone who actually respects you. What's the difference? Everything. First time we met up, I told her the plan. I pick you up from school, walk you to your car, hold your hand in the hallways. Normal boyfriend stuff, but visible. That's it? That's it. No drama, no threats, just presents. Phoebe looks skept. Austin's not going to back down from hand holding, trust me. The first two days were weird. Phoebe's friends kept staring at us like I was some zoo animal. Whispers followed us down every hallway. What's she doing with him? Isn't that the kid who works at Save Mart? Phoebe heard it, too. I could see her jaw tighten every time someone made a comment. You don't have to do this, I told her after some girl made a crack about my thrift store jacket. Yes, I do, she said, squeezing my hand tighter. Sure enough, Austin showed up the third day. Massive dude, varsity jacket, looked pissed as hell. Who's this? He demanded, getting right in Phoebe's face like I wasn't even there. I stepped between them. Calm. No

For those who grew up poor, what did you consider a luxury? I never invited anyone to my house, not because I didn't want to, but because I knew they'd ask questions I didn't have good answers for. Why do you only have one bed for the whole family? Why does your fridge only have condiments and expired milk? Why does it smell like gas near the heater that barely works? And Jake, this new kid in my 7th grade class, invited me to his birthday sleepover. I almost said no. My parents always said sleepovers were too risky, too weird. But really, they just didn't want anyone figuring out how broke we were. But something about Jake seemed different. He wasn't trying to impress anyone, so I said yes. Walking into Jake's house felt like stepping onto another planet. The carpet was thick and soft under my feet. I'd never walked on carpet that wasn't stained or worn down to the backing. Their bathroom had two sinks, two. I stood there staring at them like they were alien technology. Jake had his own room with L E. D strip lights around the ceiling, a t V. Mounted on the wall, and his own mini fridge full of soda does and energy drinks. I must have stared at that fridge for too long because Jake laughed and said I could grab whatever I wanted at home. We shared one flat Coke between three people when mom could afford it, when Jake opened his dresser to pick pajamas. I actually asked out loud, you have choices. He looked at me weird but didn't say anything mean, just tossed me an extra pair of pajamas that were cleaner than anything I owned. Dinner wasn't even fancy, just burgers and fries from the grill outside. But I couldn't remember the last time I ate something that wasn't microwaved leftovers or ramen noodles. The burger had real lettuce, tomatoes, cheese that was actually melted, pickles that weren't from a jar we'd had for six months. Finished my plate in like three minutes and then just sat there, not sure if asking for more would be rude. Jake's mom noticed and said, want another one? There's plenty. I nodded so fast I probably looked desperate. When we went to sleep, Jake gave me my own blanket, my own pillow. I didn't even know how to act at home. Me and my little brother shared a twin mattress on the floor, switching sides every night because one side was closer to the broken heater that made this horrible rattling noise. I couldn't fall asleep for hours, not because I was uncomfortable, but because everything was too comfortable, too quiet, too warm, too safe. That's when it hit me that the biggest luxury wasn't the food or the room or even having my own space. It was peace. Just pure, simple peace. The next morning, Jake's mom made pancakes from scratch, not the boxed mix we sometimes Got on birthdays, but real pancakes with syrup that wasn't corn syrup in a fake maple bottle. She asked if I wanted chocolate chips in mine. I said yes, even though I'd never had chocolate chip pancakes before. I didn't tell Jake the truth about my house, but when his mom drove me home and I saw him looking at our apartment building with its busted front door and the smell of cigarettes in the hallway, I felt ashamed, not of my family, but of the whole situation we couldn't control. Before I got out of the car, Jake asked if I wanted to hang out again next weekend, not at his house, just at the park or something. I realised he wasn't being nice because he felt sorry for me. He just liked hanging out. That sleepover changed something in me. I started working harder in school, not because I wanted to get rich or anything dramatic like that, but because I wanted to feel that peace again. I wanted a life where I didn't have to worry about whether the power would get shut off or whether we'd have enough food for the week. Now I'm in college and I have my own dorm room, my own bed, my own desk, my own mini fridge.

Back in middle school, me and my friends actually made our own secret language to pass notes. At first, we tried writing backwards so if teachers or classmates tried to peek, they couldn't read it quickly. But then we realized if our notebooks ever got confiscated, it would still be easy to figure out. So we went full spy mode. We created a whole alphabet, gave each letter its own symbol, and memorized it. Suddenly, we could write full conversations in class, and no one had a clue what we were saying. Bye, high school. We didn't really use it anymore, but I still had all the symbols memorized. One day, I was in class journaling about a crush in the back of my notebook. I wasn't disrupting anyone, but my teacher noticed how into it I was and decided to call me out. He goes, what, are you writing a book over there? Clearly those aren't notes. I froze, snapped the notebook shut immediately. Thankfully, he just made a little joke and moved on. But there was no way I was about to risk my thoughts about this girl being read out loud to the whole class. So the next time I journaled, I switched back. Back to the secret language. To everyone else, it looked like I was just doodling random symbols, but to me, it was the perfect cover. Fast forward. Years later, I find those old notebooks again. And the problem. I had thrown away the Only translator we ever made. Which means all the secrets I wrote as a kid are now locked away forever. In a language even I don't understand anymore. Guys, what do I do?

Do you guys ever get that heavy feeling when you realise you're not really a priority to anyone? Like, I feel like I only exist when my friends are bored, lonely or need something from me. Whenever I need them, I'm left on delivered for hours, sometimes all day. It's like I'm just a second option or a last option. And honestly, sometimes I'm not even an option at all. They never prioritize me. They never make time unless it's convenient for them. And the worst part, I still show up for them. Every single time.

Bro, nothing cracks me up more than the sorry for the late reply text. Like late. That wasn't late. That was a whole ghosting session. You disappeared for 24 hours like you were filming an episode of survivor and then they pop back like, oops, I was busy, busy with what? A NASA mission. You didn't just reply late. You respond after a whole day cycle. Honestly, don't say late reply. Just admit you didn't feel like texting me back. Be real because if I vanish for 24 hours, trust people are filing a missing person's report.

Why the hell are 45 minute classes treated like a prison sentence? Like, bro, 45 minutes doesn't sound bad until you're sitting there watching the clock tick slower than your Wi-Fi when it's buffering. And then on top of that, zero recess. None. Like, sorry, when did we sign up for corporate America? At age 15, you expect me to sit through seven classes straight? No break, no sunlight, just pure fluorescent lighting and trauma? By third period, my brain's gone, my soul's gone, and my will to live is on the attendance sheet marked absent. At this point, recess isn't a luxury, it's a human right.
NA

Bro, when my parents say we need to talk, I mentally start planning my fucking funeral. Like, why you gotta say it like that? Just say what it's about. Give me a hint, a theme, a fucking trailer. The second I hear we need to talk, my brain's like, that's it. They found out everything. Even the shit I didn't do yet. I'm sweating, I'm pacing. I'm suddenly remembering lies I told four years ago. I'm like, was it the grades, the charger I stole in 2019? That one time I said, okay with attitude, bro, I'm sitting on the couch like I'm waiting for a death sentence. Then they finally say, you've been leaving dishes in the sink. Like, why the fuck you build it up? Like I just committed war crimes.

Why is there always that one person who's never seen without a vape? Like bro, do you even breathe air? They hit that thing like it's their life support. One puff every five seconds. You'll be mid conversation and suddenly cloud of blueberry vanilla Ice Blast hits your face like a smoke machine at a concert. And it's always the wildest flavors too. Dragon blood watermelon cotton candy explosion or some nonsense. I'm like bro, that's not a snack, that's battery powered diabetes. And what kills me is they always say I'm not addicted though, while their vape is literally on a lanyard like a damn necklace. Take one deep breath without it. I dare you. Their lungs probably smell like a Yankee Candle store at this point. They don't even exhale, they just exist in mist.
NA

I don't know how to explain it, but I really love people who make sure I don't feel left out. Like, it's the little things, when they slide me into the conversation or when they make sure I'm included in the plans. It just means so much. It makes you feel like you actually matter to them. And that feeling, that's something I'll never take for granted. Well, anyways, thanks. Out. Mwah.

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favorite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.
