At first, we tried writing backwards so if teachers or classmates tried to peek, they couldn't read it quickly. But then we realized if our notebooks ever got confiscated, it would still be easy to figure out. So we went full spy mode. We created a whole alphabet, gave each letter its own symbol, and memorized it. Suddenly, we could write full conversations in class, and no one had a clue what we were saying. In high school, we didn't really use it anymore, but I still had all the symbols memorized. One day, I was in class journaling about a crush in the back of my notebook. I wasn't disrupting anyone, but my teacher noticed how into it I was and decided to call me out. He goes, what, are you writing a book over there? Clearly those aren't notes. I froze. Snap the notebook shut immediately. Thankfully, he just made his little joke and moved on. But there was no way I was about to risk my thoughts about this girl being read out loud to the whole class. So the next time I journaled, I switched back to the secret language. To everyone else, it looked like I was just doodling random symbols, but to me, it was the perfect cover. Fast forward. Years later, I find those old notebooks again. And the problem. I had thrown away the only Translator we ever made. Which means all the secrets I wrote as a kid are now locked away forever in a language even I don't understand anymore. Guys, what do I do?

They just found a mosquito with actual Dinosaur DNA frozen in amber. Like this is literally the plot of Jurassic Park. Did nobody watch the movie? We all saw how that went down. And, you know, some scientist right now is rubbing his hands together like, hey, hey, let's break. Bring back a t. Rex. No, put that bug back in the ice where you found it, bro. If they make a real life Jurassic Park, it's over. We can't even handle regular animals. People out here getting chased by geese and you think we're ready for velociraptors? Imagine walking your dog and a raptor just hops out the bushes like, yo, what's for dinner? And, you know, some rich dudes go, I pay $10,000 to pet a baby triceratops then cry when it eats his car. We already got mutant wasps, the plague, and now dinosaurs, 2,025. Really speed running the apocalypse. Somebody lock that mosquito back up before it hatches the boss fight of humanity.

Bro, why is the weekend only two days? Like who decided that was enough? Two days, that's not a break. That's a prank. Like I touch my bed on Friday and the next thing I know the alarms ringing and it's Monday morning. And honestly, who even invented the 7 day week? Like what if there's actually supposed to be 10 or 18 days and we all just got scammed? And why is the ratio five days of pain to two days of peace? That's like ordering a pizza and only getting two slices. Because here's the thing, the weekend is not even a real weekend. Friday night is gone in a blink. Saturday doesn't even exist. It's more like catch up on chores day and Sunday is finish all the homework you got day. Like why do we even get homework? Is the weekend not supposed to be the week's end? Am I not supposed to rest? Meanwhile, school takes five whole days, 5. Imagine working five shifts at a job you never applied for and the pay, see you again on Monday. Like, bro, at least jobs give you money. School gives you stress exams, annoying teachers and fire drills at 8:00am when it's freezing outside. Honestly, I wish we could flip it. Two days of school, 5 days of weekend, that's balance. That's peace. Until then, I'll be sitting in class every Monday wondering if dropping out is a spiritual call. No.

We might actually be fucked. You mean to tell me we just fired a missile at a UFO and it deflected it? Look at this. That was a 200 pound missile and it shrugged it off like it was nothing. How is this not a bigger deal? We just fired top tier military tech at something that doesn't even react. Like, it didn't dodge, it didn't block, it just let the missile hit and kept floating. That's not defense, that's disrespect. And we're sitting here like, maybe it's peaceful. Well, it's a bit late for peace when we're the ones firing missiles at it immediately. You don't get to throw hands and then act surprised when it looks back. It was just floating there, minding its business. We threw the first punch, it didn't even blink. And now we're all just standing around like that's normal. If it ever turns around and starts charging up, we're cooked. 2,025 cannot get any crazier. But hey, at least it's ending with a bang. Follow for more daily rants!

Why are school desks literally designed for human suffering? Like bro, these things aren't furniture. They're weapons. The seat is welded to the desk at the worst angle possible, like it was built for a different species. You sit down and it feels less like learning and more like punishment. They're literally built to hurt you. The second you lean back, your spine folds in half. 10 minutes in, your back is screaming. By the end of class, you're walking out shaped like a question Mark. And don't even get me started on the size. The surface is so small it rejects everything you put on it. Pencil falls off, paper slides off, laptop hanging off the edge like it's trying to escape. It's like the desk itself doesn't want you to succeed. And the movement is insane. Even the smallest adjustment makes it creek like it's 200 years old. You lean on it for half a second and the whole thing starts rocking like a seesaw. And underneath, gum, always gum. Not just one kid's gum, decades of it. Generations of students have all suffered in the same chair and left their Mark like a time capsule of pain. These things aren't here to help you learn. They're slow torture devices disguised as desks. And every single one was designed to make you suffer. Follow for more daily rants.

You know what, guys? I'm gonna say it. I hate Bacons, and I've always been with the anti bacon agenda. I've kept it a secret for so long, but now I can't help but reveal my secret animosity for them. And hear me out, I'm not saying all bacons, just a specific type. So first off, you can easily tell if a bacon is actually new to Roblox compared to a bacon that intentionally uses bacon hair for their Avatar. I don't hate the new bacons at all. They're just probably babies tapping on their ipads. I'm talking about the intentional bacons. These little rats make me want to scream in every single game I play because. Tell me why I'm playing a game where it's a FFA that clearly states no teams. Then one bacon goes. Bacon Brothers, we must stick together. Buddy, who do you think you are? You're not Muhammad Ali with the way you're running five versus one against everyone in the server. This has been going on for years, and especially ever since the slender shifted the robloxian balance and started making the bacons the main priority. Where was this hype when the guests were being abused back when they were on the platform?

I don't know how to explain it, but I really love people who make sure I don't feel left out. Like it's the little things when they slide me into the conversation or when they make sure I'm included in the plans. It just means so much. It makes you feel like you actually matter to them. And that feeling, that's something I'll never take for granted. Well, anyways, thanks out Mwah.

The right person, the wrong time, the right script, the wrong line, the right poem, the wrong rhyme. With a piece of you that shouldn't be mine. Maybe someday you'll say she's mine. Because love can't be hidden. Unless it's forbidden. But it isn't right. Your feelings for me grew while my feelings flew. I don't even think yours were ever true. Even I don't know. I'll make sure my feelings stay flowed. Our time will be right. Maybe sometime our script will be right. We must use the right line or we will not align. Our rhyme will be right. I know it this time. But every time I do try, it doesn't work. It doesn't match, let alone attach. The piece I want of you was never true. Getting me blue. But I get it now. You never liked me. Not because it wasn't true. It's because our feelings always flew.

Guys, y'all do not know how annoying it is to be colorblind. Like, you're just chilling with your friends and then you tell them, or they find out that you're colorblind, they will begin to ask the dumbest question, like, what colour is my shirt? Or what colour is the grass? Like, your shirt is purple. And then they say, no, it's blue. Like, bro, it isn't my fault that I didn't know that because I see purple. And then as soon as they know it, they'll tell their friends like, bro, did you know he's colorblind? And then in one second, everyone comes and asks me questions. And then there is that one time I was with a friend, we got out of the store, and I see a purple bicycle with green wheels. So I say, bro, what is that combination, bro? Like, purple and green? And then he says, bro, that's blue. And I say, no. And then he calls an old man and says, sir, that bicycle is blue, right? And that gentleman says, yes, and then he says, well, that guy says it's purple. Or one time I saw someone drawing with gray, and I asked him, dude, why are you coloring with gray? And he says, uh, bro, it's dark green.

I remember when I was 9, I found out that calling people pretty made them smile, so I'd go around saying it to literally everyone. Classmates, teachers, even random strangers. I was like, you're so pretty to anyone who'd listen. I remember one time at the grocery store, there was this cashier who always looked super tired, like she hated her job. I walked up with my mom and just said, you're really pretty. She froze for a second, then her whole face lit up. She laughed, thanked me, and even gave me a sticker from the I thought I just unlocked some Secret Life hack. Say nice things, make people happy. My mom eventually pulled me aside and was like, why do you keep doing that? And I told her, because it makes people smile. Like it was that simple to me. I just like making people happy for a second. And now these nine year olds in my comment section are calling me cybiao. Like, bro, I don't even know what that means, but judging by the way they're spamming it, I don't think it means.

Why are school icebreakers so awkward? Like, bro, it's the first day of school, you wish it was summer again. Then the teacher hits you with the most cursed phrase in the universe. Let's go around the room, introduce yourself and tell us one fun thing you did this summer. Suddenly you're on a timer. You have to invent a fun thing that sounds cool but not like you're bragging. It's a high stakes social mission. And there's always that one kid who says something like, I spent a month backpacking through Europe and then I went scuba diving in Australia, bro. Oh, calm down. We get it. You're a world traveler. Then you have the goofball who just lies for no reason. He'll say, I fought a shark and won. Wrap it up, bro. No one believes you. And you always have the person who just says, I slept, bro. That's the most low effort answer in human history. But the worst part is when they make you play two truths and a lie. It's a like interrogation. Some kid will be like, I've met the president, I have a pet alligator and I can speak fluent French. And you know for a fact two of those are probably true because this school is a fever dream. This isn't a fun get to know you game. It's a social experiment in anxiety and deception. I'm completely cooked.

Why is it that when you sneeze in class 10, people gotta yell bless you! Like they're casting a spell? Like, bro, I just sneezed, not summoned a demon. Why did I just get blessed by the entire student council? And it's never normal either. One kids whispering bless you like he's in a horror movie, another kids yelling from the back of the room like it's a military command. There's always that one girl who says bless you like she's singing the national anthem. And the teacher, they just pause and stare like I just committed a federal crime. Like, sorry for having a functioning immune system, Margaret. And here comes Dylan, who only speaks once every six months, saying god bless your soul, bro. Are you my priest now? Don't even think about sneezing twice. Oh no, now you've triggered the second blessing protocol. People start giggling, someone says you good! Like I just came back from war and Kyle in the corner starts clapping like I landed a plane. I still haven't recovered from the last time when they blessed me in three different languages. Someone threw a pencil like it was a ritual offering. Next time I sneeze, I'm leaving the room. Y'all not about to turn me into a classroom event again. Subscribe to this!

Why are wasps the main villains of the sun? Like bro. A bee is a neutral good character. It's just flying around pollinating flowers, minding its own business. It's an NPC on a peaceful side quest. If you don't bother it, it won't bother you. It's just a chill guy. But a wasp. A wasp is chaotic evil. It was created by the universe for the sole purpose of causing problems. It's spawns into the world and chooses violence. It has no mission other than to ruin your day. It doesn't even have a reason. It just wants to see the world burn. And don't even get me started on the sting. A bee stings you as a last resort. A final self destruct move. It's a kamikaze. But a wasp will sting you seven times just because you looked at it wrong. It's not self defense, it's a full blown assault for no reason. A bee is a fuzzy cute little guy. A wasp looks like it was designed in a lab to be the final boss of all insects. Mean. It's mean. It's a flying needle of pure hatred. One is a productive member of society and the other is a literal winged demon. If I see a bee, I'm cool. If I see a wasp, my soul is leaving my body, I'm completely cooked.

While waiting for my daughter to finish school, a parent turned to me and asked, did your ex husband have a beard? I giggled nervously. Um, yeah. Why? No, no, no, no, no! Oh! She suddenly screamed while walking as far away from me as possible. I just laughed because moms can be so weird sometimes. But the next day, my daughter came home from school crying. Mommy! Leah said her mom said she can't talk to me anymore. Leah was her best friend. I immediately took out my phone and texted her mom, asking if everything was okay. No response. I texted Emily's mom, one of the other girls in her trio. Still nothing. I had just managed to calm my baby girl down when the pizza arrived. Usually our delivery guy is the Appatron 5,000. But tonight he just set the box on my doorstep and practically ran away. George, you forgot your tip! I yelled, waving a 20. Just kept going. The next few days were insane. At my daughter's soccer practice, Helen saw me walking towards her and held her phone to her ear. No one had even called her, Helen, what's going on? She mouths sorry and walked faster. We used to complain about our husbands together. Parents were whispering and showing each other something on their phones when I walked by. They quickly put them away. By Thursday, my daughter was refusing to go to school. They moved my desk away from everyone else. Teacher said it was for space reasons, but there's like ten feet between me and Leah now. I tried to bring her to the hairdresser to cheer her up, but when the woman saw me coming, she closed early. No apology. Just flipped the sign and pulled the blinds. My phone buzzed. It was my landlord. Heard what happened. So sorry. Rent can wait this month. This was the same man who charged me a fifty dollar inconvenience it's fee when I paid rent at 12:00am instead of midnight. Then the birthday party. Emily sleepover. My daughter found out that everyone was invited except her. She was having such a bad panic attack that I had to call a hospital. Mom, what did I do? Emily is my best friend. Enough was enough. I called the school office. Something is happening to my daughter. She's being systematically excluded and I need answers right now. The counselor called back within an hour, but her voice was off. Like she was choosing every word carefully. Missus Callahan, we just wanted to check in about your home environment. Is everything safe? Anyone new spending time around your daughter? What? What are you even asking me? I think it's best if we discuss this in person. Can you come in tomorrow morning? No. You'll tell me right now why my daughter is being tortured. Long pause. The principal will explain everything tomorrow. Beep. She hung up. Then at 11 p m. An email from My gym membership terminated effective immediately. I've been going there for 5 years. The owner knew me by name. I was trying to figure out what to do when my daughter crawled into my bed at 2:00am, sobbing, Mommy, am I ugly? It took everything in me not to burst into tears. The lunch lady wouldn't look at me today. She just pointed at my tray. I finally caved. On Saturday morning, I found myself walking towards the principal's office while being escorted by a security guard. Other parents there for Saturday sports hold their kids against the walls as we passed. One mom literally shielded her son with her body, like we were dangerous. In his office, the principal locked the door behind us. The click was so loud in the silence, he walked to the windows and twisted the blinds shut. My daughter grabbed my hand tighter. Please sit down. I'll stand. What is this about? He sat at his desk, fingers hovering over his keyboard, then pulled them back. Mister Griffin, you're scaring me. Missus Callahan. He was looking at his screen, not at me.
NA

Everyone in my family knew my dad was the most devoted father on earth. He sacrificed everything to give his kids a better life than he ever had. He sold his truck to pay for my sister's emergency surgery when insurance said they wouldn't cover it. He worked triple shifts for six months straight to afford my brother's rehab. He even quit his job when I was getting bullied so he could homeschool me for a year. Three weeks was all the doctors gave him after finding tumors everywhere. The 40 years of breathing factory chemicals to support us finally caught up to him. They set him up with home hospice care so he could die in his own bed. He called all of us kids together on Facetime. Since my siblings lived states away, all he wanted was at least one day with each of us before he died. Nothing complicated, he said with that raspy voice the cancer gave him. Just come sit with your old man one more time. I promised him I would be there every single day since I lived 20 minutes away. My siblings swore they would come in immediately to take their turns with him. The morning my sister was supposed to arrive, dad woke up at five in the morning to get ready. The morphine made him dizzy, but he shaved, combed his hair and put on his good flannel shirt anyway. He spent three hours making her favourite cinnamon rolls from Scratch. He had to keep sitting down to breathe, but he finished them. I got there at nine to help him set everything up. Then he sat in his recliner by the window and watched for her all morning. Around 10, he said maybe her flight was delayed, but we both knew that wasn't true. By noon, she still hadn't shown up. When he called her, it went straight to voicemail, and she left all of his texts on read. Around dinner time, she finally texted him back and said her law firm had an emergency. But two hours later, she posted photos from a beachside restaurant where she was having dinner with her friends. I held his hand while he cried for the first time since mom died. The cinnamon rolls sat on touched until I threw them away after he cried himself to sleep. My brother was supposed to come the next day. Dad had me pull out the photo albums from when we were kids. He kept touching the pictures of my brother's first day of school and telling me stories I'd heard a hundred times. My brother called that morning and said, dad, I'm definitely coming, but this client meeting got moved to noon, and it's a million dollar deal, so just give me a few more hours. Dad waited in that recliner all day, but he never showed up. That night, I saw my brother posting videos from a bar. He was doing shots with Co workers and celebrating some deal they closed. Dad asked me to put the photo albums away, looking defeated. Least I have you, he whispered. The next morning, his hospice nurse, Nancy, came for her regular visit and immediately knew something was wrong. She checked his vitals and told me he was declining much faster than expected and might only have hours left. Dad asked Nancy to call my siblings for him. I sat there holding Dad's hand while she begged them to come say goodbye to him while they still could. She put it on speaker so dad could hear everything. My sister spoke first. Oh, my god. Is he seriously doing this right now? Class like dad. He always has to make everything about him. This is just another guilt trip, and I'm not falling for it. My brother jumped in next. He chose that toxic factory job over spending time with us, and now he wants us to drop everything because he. He's dying from it. That is actually hilarious. Then my sister said the worst thing possible. Tell him, I said. Thanks for the college money, but I am not wasting my vacation days to watch him rot. Dad's entire face changed into something I had never seen before. Pure ice. After they hung up, he was silent for a full minute. Then he said, call my lawyer right now. Tell him it is an emergency. Lawyer arrived within an hour with a notary. Dad signed Everything with steady hands. And recorded a video with the lawyer's phone. My two oldest children just taught me something important, he said to the camera. They think visiting me before I die is a waste of their vacation days. So they won't get a single penny when I'm gone. Everything I spent 40 years destroying my body for will go to the two people who were here for me while I died. My nurse Nancy, held my hand through hell. And my youngest never left my side. He stared straight at the lens. I spent my whole life proving I loved you both. But you just proved you never loved me back. Congratulations. You're both orphans now. Later that night, dad died with Nancy and me beside him. The house went to me and his entire safe.
NA

Girlfriend said, you're my boyfriend, so act like one. So I did exactly that and watched her world crumble. She watched me get down on one knee five times and said no every single time. Eight years together, I've been playing husband since year two, paying her car note, keeping her on my insurance, covering most of the rent while she found herself through three different careers. She had this whole routine down, tears in her eyes, hand on her heart. Then some perfectly rehearsed excuse, we're not ready. Let's wait till we're more stable. The timing isn't right. Then came proposal No. 5, and she finally showed me who she really was. I'd gone all out this time, convinced myself that maybe the problem was I hadn't made it special enough. I rented out her favourite restaurants, rooftop, hung string lights everywhere and invited all our friends and family there. The whole production cost me three months salary, but I thought it'd be worth it when she finally said yes. My girlfriend stood there in the dress I'd bought her, surrounded by everyone we knew, and she didn't even let me finish the speech. Just shook her head with this pitying smile like I was a dog that wouldn't stop bringing her the same stick. Back at our apartment that night, I finally broke, asked her straight up if she loved me. Why did she keep doing this? Her whole face changed in an instant and the mask came. Completely off. It's my choice when I accept a proposal, she said. Voice ice cold. You don't get to pressure me with your timeline. You're my boyfriend, so act like one. Stop trying to be my husband when I haven't even accepted your proposal. Know your place. Know my place. For eight years of building a life together, I was supposed to know my place. Those words rewired something in my brain. Eight years of playing husband while she kept me a boyfriend status because it was convenient for her. She wanted me to act like a boyfriend. Fine. I give her exactly what she asked for. But boyfriends don't pay their girlfriends bills. Boyfriends don't share bank accounts. Boyfriends don't sacrifice their futures for someone who won't even wear their ring. I started my new boyfriend only policy the next this morning while she was at her yoga class. First, I sold the ring to a dealer for 12 grand, enough to cover what I'd spent on her car this year alone. Then I called Verizon and removed her from my phone plan. The time she got home from yoga, I changed every password and moved my money from our joint account. She didn't even notice until lunch when her phone died mid phone call. Babe, my phone's not working, she texted from her laptop, annoyed but not worried. Call Verizon. It's being weird. An hour later, they said I'm not on the account anymore. Then the panic started. Creeping in. What did you do? I responded, I'm being your boyfriend and not.
NA
NA
NA

Little sister has had a crush on my husband, but she never expected to get humiliated in such a way. My younger sister Ariana turned into a homewrecker the moment my husband Kevin slipped the ring on my finger and started a desperate pick me routine. If Kevin were blue, she'd show up in blue. If you mentioned liking something, she'd become an expert overnight. If he posted about a restaurant, she coincidentally appeared during our date. It started subtle, almost innocent. Even like sitting next to Kevin at every family dinner, Ariana would squeeze between us, claiming she couldn't hear from the other end. I didn't mind since family is family. But after six months, it got obvious. Kevin joined a gym near his office. Ariana got a membership there the next day, showing up during his workout times and tiny sports bras. Kevin mentioned liking astronomy once. Suddenly, Ariana was texting him NASA articles daily, asking, can you explain? Then came the fake emergencies. Her car broke down near Kevin's office. Her apartment had a gas leak when I was out of town. She needed help moving heavy boxes that turned out to be empty, Kevin always told me, immediately showing me her texts with eye rolls. She's just young and confused, he'd say. And I agreed until she officially went too far. A hard knock at 9:00am and there stood Ariana in a tiny white sundress, full makeup, hair curled like a magazine shoot. I need Kevin's Help moving furniture, she announced, pushing past me. Where is he? But we both knew she lived in a furnished apartment. I was about to tell her to leave when she added, I'm sure you have errands to run. You can go away now. She was literally trying to dismiss me from my own home. Kevin came downstairs and she immediately grabbed his arm. Oh, perfect. You're already dressed. I promise I'll return him in one piece. She actually winked at me. I felt my chest burn with rage, but then had a different thought. I headed upstairs, loudly saying, I need to take a bath. But I didn't leave or go to the bathroom. I stayed upstairs where I could hear everything through the vents. She didn't waste any time. Oh, my God, Kevin, you're so muscular, she giggled, clearly touching his arm. Do you work out every day? I bet you could lift me with one hand. Wanna try? I rolled my eyes. This girl had zero shame. I kept holding laundry, waiting for Kevin's polite deflection. Instead, I heard him say, seriously, Ariana, can I tell you something important? My heart sank. Oh, god, here we.

Things that boys do when they like you. First thing, he'll try to make you laugh, even if it means making a fool of himself. Your smile is worth it. TikTok can reveal who secretly likes you. It's the second person that shows up when you click share. Then more. Boys will often find excuses to be around you, like asking for your help or accidentally bumping into you. 20 million people have the same birthday as you. Write yours in the comments to see who shares it. If he's always the first to view your stories or react to your posts, it's because he's keeping an eye on what you're up to. Most people's phone doesn't have this secret emoji. Just comment star in square brackets to unlock it. Boys might act more confident or try to impress you when they're around you. It's their way of catching your attention. If you wanna know more signs like this, follow now because you won't wanna miss what's next. When a guy likes you, he'll find ways to touch you, even if it's just a friendly pat on the back or a high five. If he remembers tiny details you've mentioned, like your favourite song or a story from months ago, he's definitely interested. Hit like if you've seen these signs before, and drop a comment if you think someone's been showing them to you. And here's the last one. Boys might tease or playfully annoy you, but it's just their way Of getting closer and seeing your reaction.

What's your perfect example of play stupid games, win stupid prizes? My high school made all the boys holding their pee because someone wrote hi on the wall in Sharpie. Monday morning we all showed up to find a sign taped to the boys bathroom door. Closed until further notice due to vandalism. The girls bathroom was still open, of course, but our school only had one bathroom for boys in the entire building because it was an old school built in the 60s when they apparently thought teenage boys never needed to pee. Principal Carpenter made an announcement during first period. Due to the disrespectful graffiti found in the boys restroom, this facility will remain locked until someone comes forward with information about who did it. The entire male population of our high school groaned at the same time. The crazy part was what the graffiti actually said. My friend Peyton had seen it Friday before they locked everything up. Someone had written HI in tiny letters on the bathroom stall. Not a curse word, not a drawing. Just HI I in black Sharpie about the size of a quarter. By lunch, the situation was getting desperate. Guys were asking teachers for hall passes to go to the nurse's office just to use that bathroom. But the school nurse caught on quick and started turning people away unless they were actually sick. Some guys tried using the staff bathroom, but got detention for that. A few desperate souls walked To the gas station across the street during lunch. But security started watching for that, too. We tried talking to Principal Carpenter. Reasonably. Group of five guys went to his office to explain that punishing 300 boys for one tiny word was insane. He sat behind his big desk with his arms crossed. Actions have consequences. When the vandal comes forward, everyone gets bathroom privileges back. By Wednesday, things were getting bad. Guys were dehydrated from not drinking water all day. The basketball team couldn't practice properly because half the players were holding it in. Parents started calling to complain. The carpenter wouldn't budge. He sent out an email saying this was a lesson in collective responsibility. That's when Dean Patterson had his brilliant idea. He was this quiet kid.

At my graduation dinner, everyone was laughing until grandma smiled at me and said, I'm glad the 3,000 I send you each month is helping. I paused, looked around, and said, I never got any money. The entire table went silent. You could hear the clinking of silverware from other tables, but at ours, dead quiet. My parents froze. My dad's fork literally clattered onto his plate, and my mom's hand started shaking as she reached for her wine glass. What do you mean you never got any money? Grandma asked, her voice getting that sharp edge I remembered from when she caught my cousins lying as kids. My mom cleared her throat nervously. Mother, we can explain this later. No! Grandma's voice cut through the air like a knife. Explain it now. I've been sending three thousand dollar checks to Monica every single month since Aubrey started college. Where is that money? My brain was spinning. Three thousand dollars a month for four years. I started doing the math in my head while everyone stared at me. That's when my little sister Savannah, who'd been scrolling through Instagram this whole time, suddenly looked up. Oh, wait. Is that where mom got the money for my BMW? If the table was quiet before, now it was like a tomb. Savannah, shut up! My mom hissed, but it was too late. And my spring break trip to Cancun last month, Savannah continued, completely oblivious to the horror spreading across everyone's faces. And that designer bag you bought me for Christmas. I felt like I was watching my life in slow motion. Four years. Four brutal years of working three jobs just to afford ramen noodles and textbooks. 60 hour work weeks while my parents took family vacations. Sleeping in a moldy basement apartment while my sister got a luxury car you stole from me. I said, my voice barely a whisper. My dad finally found his voice. Aubrey, Sweetheart, it's not what it looks like. Really? I stood up, my chair scraping against the floor. Because it looks like you watched me destroy my health. Working multiple jobs while you used my money to spoil Savannah. The restaurant felt like it was spinning. I remembered all those phone calls home, begging for help with textbooks, with rent, with groceries. All those times they said money was tight, they couldn't help. I needed to learn responsibility. How much? Grandma's voice was ice cold. I did the math out loud, my voice getting stronger with each. No. 3,000 * 12 months times four years. $144,000. My mom started crying. We were going to pay it back when you graduated. With what money? I laughed, but there was no humor in it. You don't have that kind of cash lying around. You spend it all on Savannah's lifestyle. Savannah finally looked up from her phone, realize. I think this was about her. Wait, so I have to give the car back? Are you serious? Right now. I turned to her. You're worried about keeping a car that was bought with stolen money while I've been eating peanut butter sandwiches for dinner? That's when Uncle Stewart would've been unusually quiet. Spoke up Monica

Holy shit. What is wrong with September? It's only been 11 days and the world is completely off its fucking rocker. Charlie Kirk was killed in front of his family. David was found with a body in his car. A Ukrainian girl was stabbed on the subway. And now Elon Musk isn't even the richest man on the planet anymore. Like, can we chill for one second? First, Charlie Kirk got shot during a speech in Utah. He was literally in front of his wife and kids when a bullet entered his artery through his neck. The scene was so bloody and gruesome, it's insane. A Ukrainian girl gets stabbed on a train in Charlotte. She escaped a literal war, came here to be safe and still got killed because this planet has zero peace. Then D4D has a whole body in his car, like not a metaphorical one, an actual human body in a bag in his trunk. And this dude just casually performed like he didn't have a horror movie in his backseat. What the hell? And even outside all of that, Elon Musk is no longer the richest person in the world, losing his top spot to a rival tech CEO, showing how unstable everything feels right now, even at the highest levels. It's like every time I open my phone, reality speed runs another tragedy. Like, bro, it's been 11 days. September just started. I thought my only problem this month would be math class, but no, apparently It's full blown world collapse. Society isn't just cooked, it's burnt to ash.

We all have that one friend who never fucking sleeps. Like I don't know if he's part vampire or a fucking robot. You ask him, yo, you gonna sleep tonight? And he looks at you dead in the eyes like sleep is for weaklings, bro. We'll be chilling at like 2:00am and he's just wide awake scrolling on his phone acting like he's some kind of badass. And I'm over here like, dude, you're gonna crash eventually. And he just laughs like sleep is a myth or something. But it gets worse the next day he's somehow still full of energy looking like he's ready to fight a fucking bear. And I can barely get out of bed without turning into a zombie, bro. How does your body not just give up? You're walking around like some kind of immortal anime character and I swear the government should be studying you. And the worst part, he flexes it. Oh yeah, I didn't sleep last night. Congrats bro. You're tired. Oh wait, no, you're not. Meanwhile, I yawn every five seconds like a human malfunctioning. Give it five years and he's gonna be running marathons at 3:00am while the rest of us are still crying over our alarms get up.
NA

Why are schools banning phones like we're in prison? Like, bro, the second the bell rings, teachers act like we're trying to smuggle contraband across the border. They see a phone, and suddenly they're the FBI and their excuses. It's a distraction, bro. So is Kyle trying to balance a pencil on his upper lip for 40 minutes. Nobody banned that. It hurts your focus, and staring at a wall for 50 minutes during a lecture on mitochondria is supposed to build character? The worst part is how dramatic they make it. They'll stand in front of the class and say, this is for your own good, like they're saving us from some evil curse. Bro, it's TikTok, not black magic. And don't even get me started on those phone jails. Those little pouches they lock your phone in like it's doing a life sentence. You can hear it buzzing, crying for help, but you can't touch it. It's like watching your child get kidnapped. Then the teachers will pull the classic, back in my day, we didn't need phones. Yeah, back in your day, you also thought smoking indoors was fine and cars didn't have seatbelts. Times change, UNC. This isn't school, it's a boot camp. I'm completely cooked. Follow for more daily rants.
NA

What's the dumbest reason your daughter stopped talking to you? Oh, honey, let me tell you about the time my daughter didn't talk to me for two whole weeks because I betrayed her trust over a damn chicken nugget. So my daughter Lila, she's 14, has the attitude of a Beverly Hills housewife and the budget of a toddler. This girl acts like she's the CEO of the household, tells me things like, mom, please don't embarrass me in front of my friends. Just stand still and blink like, ma'am, you live in my uterus rent free for nine months. Show some respect. Anyway, she decides she's going vegan. Great. I support her. I buy tofu, almond milk, overpriced plant nuggets that taste like regret, the whole shebang. Do I understand it? No. But I'm a supportive queen. But then one night it's 1:00am, I'm watching reality TV in the dark and I get hungry. I open the freezer and see those dino shaped chicken nuggets she begged for last year and never ate. So I pop like 4 in the air fryer. I'm minding my business, living my best life life. And guess what? I forget to hide the evidence. Next morning she walks into the kitchen, sniffs the air like a bloodhound and goes, did you eat meat in this house? I said, um, maybe. She gasps like I just committed war crimes. You ate dead animals while I was sleeping. I said, baby girl, they were shaped like Dinosaurs, they're barely meat. Calm down. She grabs her reusable water bottle, slams it on the counter and yells, this is why the planet's dying, mom, because of people like you who can't control their midnight cravings. I said, okay, Greta Thunberg, relax. She storms off to her room and text me from down the hall. We're not speaking. This is a betrayal. I text back, fine, more dino nuggets from. She leaves me on read y'all. Two weeks she wouldn't speak to me, not even when I stubbed my toe and screamed so loud the neighbors checked on me. She just walked past me with her Hydro flask and judgmental aura. But then get this, one day I come home early from work. I walk into the kitchen and there she is standing in front of the microwave holding a plate with three dino nuggets. She's caught midbite. We lock eyes, time freezes. She goes, they don't count if they're Dinosaur shaped. I said, excuse me. She wipes her mouth like a criminal and goes, don't tell dad. I said, oh, I'm telling everyone. She bribes me with her leftover Starbucks gift card and begs for mercy. I post the photo in our family group chat. Anyway, catch then our little activist caught mid murder. Her grandpa replied, meet runs in the family. Her uncle sent a Dinosaur emoji. Now she talks to me again, but only if I swear never to bring it up again. And in front Of her friends. So what do I do? Oh, I bring it up at every chance, especially when they start talking about saving the turtles. Because if you're gonna give me the silent treatment over dino nuggets, you better be ready for extinction level consequences.

My stepfather called me worthless at graduation, so I saved his voicemail for the day I bought his dream house. I was valedictorian, full ride to Stanford. But all my stepfather could focus on was the empty seat where my biological father should have been sitting. After the ceremony, he pulled me aside behind the gymnasium. His face was red with that particular rage he reserved for moments when I reminded him that I wasn't his. You think you're so smart, he pissed, gripping my cap so hard the tassel snapped. Walking across that stage like you accomplished something, your real dad didn't even show up because deep down everyone knows what I know, you're worthless. Mom stood 20 feet away pretending not to see. She perfected that skill over the years. That night, drunk on wine and self importance, he left me a voicemail. I almost deleted it immediately. Instead, something made me save it. His slurred words about how college would humble me, how I'd come crawling back begging for his approval, how I'd never amount to anything without his guidance. Stanford was everything he said it wouldn't be. I thrived, made Dean's list every semester. By junior year, I was already being recruited by investment firms. During spring break of my senior year, I found my stepfather in his study surrounded by real estate magazines and architectural plans. He was obsessing over the same Victorian mansion that had been for sale in our town's historic district for Three years asking price was $2.8 million, completely beyond his reach as a middle management insurance adjuster. Someday, he told mom as I passed by, when my promotion comes through, this house represents everything I've worked for. He drive past it every weekend, slowing down to stare at the wrap around porch and turret windows. It consumed him the way some people obsess over celebrities. After graduation, I moved to New York. Within two years, I was making more money than my stepfather would see in a decade. I bought a penthouse in Manhattan, built a life he said I'd never have. But I kept thinking about that house. Last month, the Victorian was back on the market. The price had dropped to $2.4 million. I flew home that weekend and toured it with a realtor. Crown molding, original hardwood floors, a library with built in shelves reaching the ceiling. I could see why my stepfather had dreamed about it. I made an all cash offer that afternoon. The closing was scheduled for a Thursday. I drove to my mother's house afterward, the deed still warm in my hands. My stepfather was in his usual spot on the recliner watching cable news and complaining about mortgage rates. Remember that Victorian you always wanted, I asked casually. His head snapped up. The Whitmore house, what about it? I bought it today. The color drained from his face. Mom stopped folding.

What's the funniest thing someone has said while high on anesthesia? Last month, I took my girlfriend Ebony to get knee surgery after she tore her ACL playing soccer. My mom insisted on coming to the hospital because she wanted to support Ebony. Ebony goes into surgery and everything goes fine. When she wakes up in recovery, she's completely loopy from the anesthesia. The nurse warns us she might be a little confused and say some strange things. My mom immediately perks up. Oh, this should be interesting. Ebony opens her eyes and sees me first. Jake, you're so handsome, like a beautiful potato. Thanks, babe. How are you feeling? I feel like I'm floating. Am I floating? Are we in space? My mom laughs. No, sweetie, you're in the hospital. Ebony turns to look at my mom and her eyes go wide. Oh, my God. It's Jake's mom. You're so pretty. You look like Jake but with better hair. My mom is eating this up. Thank you, Ebony. I have something really important to tell you, Ebony says. Seriously? What's that, honey? Ebony motions for my mom to come closer. Come here. I need to whisper something in your ear. My mom leans in, expecting some sweet anesthesia confession. Ebony cups her hands around my mom's ear like she's about to share a deep secret. And then, but it's not just any burp. It's the loudest, longest, most obnoxious burp I've ever heard. And somehow in the middle of This massive belch, Ebony manages to say, I hate you. So what my mom hears directly in her ear is burp. I hate you. My mom jumps back like she's been attacked. What? Ebony starts giggling hysterically. I got you. I got you. So good. Ebony. Did you just burp I hate you in my ear? Maybe. Did it work? I'm trying not to laugh because my mom looks horrified. Ebony, that's my mom. I know she's great. I love her. That's why I gave her my special burp. My mom is still processing. Your special burp? Yeah, it's how I show affection. Jake gets them all the time. That's that's how you show affection. Ebony nods enthusiastically. The louder the burp, the more I love you. And that was a really loud burp. My mom looks at me. Jake, is this true? I'm bright red. Ebony has a very a unique way of expressing herself. Ebony interrupts Mrs. Simon. Wanna hear my impression of a dying whale? Ebony? No, but Ebony is already making horrible groaning sounds. Oh, the nurse comes running in. Is everything okay? Ebony waves at her. Hi, I'm practicing whale sounds. Ebony starts making clicking sound. Click, click, click. I'm talking to dolphins, my mom whispers to me. Is she always like this? Only when she's heavily medicated. Ebony overhears Mrs. Simon. Did Jake tell you about the time I accidentally called his dad daddy at dinner? Ebony, what? It was funny. Your dad turned So red, my mom is trying not to laugh. You called my husband daddy. Yeah. And then I asked him if he wanted to adopt me. Ebony, can we not tell my mom every embarrassing story right now? But I have so many good ones. Like time you cried watching The Notebook. Everyone cries watching The Notebook. You cried for two hours and then you made me watch it again. My mom is definitely laughing now. Jake cried for two hours. Ebony nod. And he ate an entire pint of ice cream with his hands. His hands. He said spoons were too slow for his emotional needs. I want to disappear. Ebony, you're supposed to be resting. I am resting. I'm resting my mouth by talking. The nurse checks Ebony's vitals. How are you feeling? I feel great. I just burped in Jake's mom's ear and told her I hate her, but I really love her. The nurse looks confused. You burped what? Ebony demonstrates by making another loud burping sound like that, but with words inside. My mom shakes her head. I've never experienced anything like that. Missus Simon, want me to teach you? Ebony, please don't teach my mom how to burp words. Why not? You never know when you might need to burp. Communicate. Ebony turns back to my mom. Missus Simon, I have another secret to tell you. My mom hesitates. Are you going to burp in my ear again? No. This is a real secret. Come closer. My mom cautiously leans in. Ebony whispered, I'm going to marry your son. My mom's face lights up. Really? Yeah. But don't tell him I'm going to propose to him, Ebony. That's not how proposals usually work. Why not? I'm a modern woman. I can post my potato boyfriend. Potato boyfriend. Ebony looks at me lovingly. Yeah, he's my beautiful potato. My mom is crying from laughing. Ebony, you're delightful. Thank you. That's why I gave you my best burp. The anesthesia starts wearing off and Ebony gets sleepy. Mrs. Simon, will you visit me when I'm not high on drugs? Of course, sweetie. Good. Next time I'll teach you my burping alphabet.

My wife said, stop trying to be romantic. It's pathetic. So I put a stop to our fake marriage. We've been married for five years and I thought I was being the perfect husband. I spent three hours cooking her favorite meal for our anniversary, set up candles, even dug out that playlist from our first date. When she walked through the door with her sister and best friend, she took one look at the setup, rolled her eyes and said loud enough for everyone to hear, stop trying to be romantic. It's pathetic. You look desperate. Then she turned to her friends. This is exactly what I was telling you about. He does this needy stuff constantly. The room went dead silent. Her sister looked uncomfortable. Her best friend stared at the floor. I stood there holding wine, watching my wife destroy our marriage with one sentence. I set the wine down, looked her straight in the eye and said, you know what, you're absolutely right. She expected me to apologize, to scramble. Instead, I started blowing out the candles. What are you doing? She asked, losing that confident edge. Stopping, I replied, gathering the flowers. Romance is pathetic when it's one sided. So I'm done being pathetic. I tossed the flowers in the trash and ordered pizza. We can eat like roommates from now on, pepperoni or cheese. That night she tried damage control, talking about bad days, overreacting. But something had shifted in me. I heard you. Perfectly, I told her. Message received. No more romantic gestures, no more pathetic behavior. She laughed it off. Maybe we both need to be more realistic about what marriage actually is. Those words would haunt her the next morning. I didn't bring her coffee in bed like I had every weekend for five years. When she came downstairs expecting her usual cup, I was finishing mine. Coffee's in the kitchen, I said. Without looking, I saw our marriage clearly for the first time. I was the one planning date nights she'd complain about. I was the one remembering anniversaries. I was the one keeping romance alive. When I stopped being romantic, I stopped with everything unnecessary. No more good morning kisses, no more asking about her day. No more caring where she went. By day 10, the cracks show. Are you going to ask me about my presentation? She said, clearly fishing. Do you want to tell me about it? Well, it went well, she said, waiting for follow up questions that never came. Good for you. I went back to my phone. She stood there for a full minute waiting for me to engage. When it became clear I wasn't playing that role anymore, she left without another word. Three weeks in, she was losing her mind. She mentioned male co workers talk about her ex reaching out, brought up how attentive other husbands were. Each comment was fishing for jealousy. Any sign I still cared. My response was Always. That's interesting. Then I'd return to whatever I was doing. I'd started hitting the gym, reading books, learn in guitar, something she'd always dismissed as a waste of time. One month in, she cracked. She was waiting at the kitchen table when I got home. Papers spread everywhere. We need to talk. You're punishing me because your feelings got hurt. My feelings got hurt. I repeated, you humiliated me in front of your friends. Called five years of romantic gesture.

Bro, why is the weekend only two days? Like, who decided that was enough? Two days? That's not a break, that's a prank. Like, I touch my bed on Friday, and the next thing I know, the alarms ringing and it's Monday morning. And honestly, who even invented the seven day week? Like, what if there's actually supposed to be 10 or 18 days and we all just got scammed? And why is the ratio five days of pain to two days of peace? That's like ordering a pizza and only getting two slices. Because here's the thing. The weekend is not even a real weekend. Friday night is gone in a blink, Saturday doesn't even exist. It's more like catch up on chores day, and Sunday is finish all the homework you got day. Like, why do we even get homework? Is the weekend not supposed to be the week's end? Am I not supposed to rest? Meanwhile, school takes five whole days. Five. Imagine working five shifts at a job you never applied for. And the pay. See you again on Monday. Like, bro, at least jobs give you money. School gives you stress, exams, annoying teachers, and fire drills at 8:00am when it's freezing outside. Honestly, I wish we could flip it. Two days of school, five days of weekend. That's balance. That's peace. Until then, I'll be sitting in class every Monday wondering if dropping out is a spiritual call. No.

A man at the art gallery told me I couldn't possibly understand the painting in front of us. I painted it. I was standing in front of my largest piece at the gallery opening, champagne in hand, when a man in an expensive suit approached and started explaining my own painting to me. He had no idea I was the artist because the placard said Riley Turner, who he clearly assumed was a man since he kept talking about his brilliant technique. This guy Robert looked me up and down and said, you seem young to be at an opening like this. Let me guess, looking for a rich boyfriend? Smart girl. Lots of wealthy men here. He gestured at my painting like he owned it. See, what Riley is doing here requires years of training to appreciate. You probably just think the colors are pretty. The average woman just sees decoration. I took a sip of champagne and said, interest in perspective, which I guess he took as encouragement. Robert moved closer to the painting, physically stepping in front of me, and continued his lecture. A Girl Like You probably thinks this is just nice to look at, but there's actual intelligence behind it. The artist is obviously a man because women simply don't have this kind of technical mastery. Female painters do. Flowers and feelings. This has real intellectual depth. It's biological, really. Men are just more capable of this level of abstraction. When I mentioned I was Familiar with the artist's work. Robert laughed and patted my shoulder. Following him on Instagram to look at the pretty pictures doesn't count as being familiar with art, sweetheart. You probably think you're cultured because you went to that Van Gogh light show. Real knowledge comes from decades of study, not whatever you Learned from TikTok. Robert decided to test me. Rapid firing questions. Who's Basquiat? What's Kiara Scuro? Name three Renaissance painters besides Da Vinci. When I started to answer, he cut me off. Wrong. See this? This is why galleries shouldn't have open events. You probably googled some terms before coming here to impress men, but Riley here is working in a tradition you couldn't possibly understand without a proper education. Not community college, sweetie. Real universities. He returned to my painting, now explaining it louder to draw a crowd. What Riley has achieved here would cost probably 100,000 in education to even the materials alone cost more than you'd make in a month at whatever retail job you have. He looked at my outfit with disgust. Target clearance rack, right? Someone who shops there couldn't possibly grasp the investment in this piece. He probably spent more on one brush than your entire outfit. When I suggested the artist might be self taught, Robert sneered at me. Is that how you Learned about art? Painting parties? Robert grabbed my wrist, only to another angle, his grip too tight. You're too stupid to even stand in the right spot. Riley intended for this to be viewed from exactly here. Your ignorance is actually disrespectful to his work. He kept his hand on my wrist while explaining, though. Honestly, explaining this to you is like teaching calculus to a toddler. You lack the basic foundation to understand any of it. He noticed me trying to pull away and

Your parent, their own worst enemy. My mom thought men were the cause of all evil. Ever since dad left us when I was 7. But that was years ago now. At 13, I had to wear this hideous shirt to school that said no boyfriends in three pink letters. She installed tracking apps, called during every free period, and even put a ring camera pointing at my bedroom window. But a small part of me understood why she was such a helicopter parent. We lived in a sketchy neighborhood. The first time I got cat called was on my eighth birthday. I was wearing a tutu skirt and with no man walking with us to protect us. We both got harassed by men all the time. So I could kind of see why she hated the male species so much. But here's the thing. All her rules didn't stop the harassment. They just made me an easier target. A girl walking alone, obviously without a boyfriend, practically wearing a sign that said vulnerable. That's when I met him. This guy from my chemistry class who noticed me speed walking past the bad corner one day, keys between my fingers, like mom taught me. Hey! He called out, you okay? I kept walking. Stranger danger and all that, but he persisted. I lived two blocks over. We could walk together. Mom's voice echoed in my head. That's how it starts. So I said no, practically ran away. But I noticed Him after that? Always seemed to be around when I was walking home. This went on for weeks. Until the day everything changed. One day, three guys started following me. My heart hammered as I fumbled for my phone. Then chemistry boy appeared. Just walked right up and put his arm around me. Hey, babe. Sorry I'm late. The guys backed off. Immediately. After they left, he dropped his arm. You good? When I nodded, he said something that made my skin prickle. I don't like you walking alone. Sweet or possessive? I couldn't tell. But either way, I was more scared of those three guys than him. So when he offered again, I finally said yes. Walks became a secret thing. Chemistry boy knew my whole schedule. Always texted home safe if he couldn't walk with me. Started teaching me self defense moves in the park. His hands adjusting my stance, showing me how to break a grip. Every girl should know this stuff, he said. But Mom's words never left my mind. Predators like to establish control. He'd appear at weird times. Just happened to be in the area. Sure. Once I joked about him following me, and his face went serious. I noticed things like that car that's been parked outside your house. I could have run then. Instead, I kept meeting him. Mom almost caught us once. I was in the middle of showing him where I lived. But I know when my mom's car turned The corner early. He practically dove behind a dumpster. My heart pounded as mom pulled up. Who are you talking to? Nobody. Just on the phone. I thought I was being so clever, sneaking around her rules. Turns out someone else was sneaking around, too, because a few days later, our neighbor, Mrs. Doyle, got robbed in broad daylight by someone who knew exactly when she'd be alone. The cop said mom went nuclear. It's always someone they trusted, someone who Learned their routine. She stared at me hard. You haven't been talking to any boys, right? I lied through my teeth while my phone buzzed. Another home safe text. Mystery Boy texted a lot. Like, a lot. Always asking where I was, who I was with. Once I didn't respond for an hour, and he showed up at the library looking panicked. Just worried, he said. Well, three weeks and two more neighborhood break ins later, I decided having him around was better than being alone. On days when my mom worked later, he'd sit in my closet doing homework while I kept watch. This is insane. Yeah, no kidding. Everything came crashing down on a Thursday. Mom came home early with a migraine. I barely got him in the closet before she walked in. Just gonna lie down, she said, heading to her room. He was trapped. My phone lit up with his text. Still in here? No sheet, Sherlock. That's when I heard it. Glass breaking downstairs. My whole body went ice cold. Mom appeared in my doorway, face white. Did you hear that? We froze as footsteps creaked on the stairs. Heavy, deliberate. Mom's eyes went wide. She mouth 9 1 1, but her phone was downstairs in her purse. Mine was dead. The foot steps got closer. My 4 eleven. Mom pushed me behind her, grabbing my field hockey stick. The door swung open. A man in a ski mask stood there, knife glinting. Mom swung the stick, but he caught it, yanked it away, shoved her heart into the wall. I screamed. The closet door exploded open. Chemistry boy launched himself at the intruder using those same moves he taught me. They crashed into the hallway. Call 9 1 1! He yelled.

Your parent, their own worst enemy. My mom thought men were the cause of all evil ever since dad left us when I was 7. But that was years ago. Now at 13, I had to wear this hideous shirt to school that said no boyfriends in three pink letters. She installed tracking apps, called during every free period and even put a ring camera pointing at my bedroom window. But a small part of me understood why she was such a helicopter parent. We lived in a sketchy neighbourhood. The first time I got cat called was on my 8th birthday. I was wearing a tutu skirt and with no man walking with us to protect us, we both got harassed by men all the time. So I could kind of see why she hated the male species so much. But here's the thing, all her rules didn't stop the harassment. They just made me an easier target. A girl walking alone, obviously without a boyfriend, practically wearing a sign that said vulnerable. That's when I met him. This guy from my chemistry class who noticed me speed walking past the bad corner one day, keys between my fingers like mom taught me. Hey, he called out, you okay? I kept walking. Stranger danger and all that. But he persisted. I live two blocks over. We could walk together. Mom's voice echoed in my head. That's how it starts. So I said no, practically ran away. But I noticed Him after that always seemed to be around when I was walking home. This went on for weeks until the day everything changed. One day, three guys started following me. My heart hammered as I fumbled for my phone. Then chemistry boy appeared. Just walked right up and put his arm around me. Hey, babe, sorry I'm late. The guys backed off immediately after they left. He dropped his arm. You good? When I nodded, he said something that made my skin prickle. I don't like you walking alone. Sweet or possessive? I couldn't tell. But either way, I was more scared of those three guys than him. So when he offered again, I finally said yes. Walks became a secret thing. Chemistry boy knew my whole schedule, always texted home safe if he couldn't walk with me. Started teaching me self defense moves in the park. His hands adjusting my stance, showing me how to break a grip. Every girl should know this stuff, he said. But Mom's words never left my mind. Predators like to establish control. He'd appear at weird times. Just happened to be in the area. Sure. Once I joked about him following me and his face went serious. I noticed things like that car that's been parked outside your house. I could have run then. Instead, I kept meeting him. Mom almost caught us once. I was in the middle of showing him where I lived. But I know when my mom's car turned The corner early. He practically dove behind a dumpster. My heart pounded as mom pulled up. Who are you talking to? Nobody. Just on the phone. I thought I was being so clever, sneaking around her rules. Turns out someone else was sneaking around too, because a few days later, our neighbor, Mrs. Doyle, got robbed in broad daylight by someone who knew exactly when she'd be alone. I lied through my teeth while my phone buzzed. Another home safe text. Mystery boy texted a lot. Like a lot. Always asking where I was, who I was with. He said, well, 3 weeks and two more neighborhood break ins later, I decided having him around was better than being alone. On days when my mom worked later, he'd sit in my closet doing homework while I kept watch. This is insane. Yeah, no kidding. Everything came crashing down on a Thursday. Mom came home early with a migraine. I barely got him in the closet before she walked in. Just gonna lie down, she said. Heading to her room. He was trapped. My phone lit up with his text, still in here. No sheet, Sherlock. That's when I heard it. Glass breaking downstairs. My whole body went ice cold. Mom appeared in my doorway, face white. Did you hear that? We froze as footsteps creaked on the stairs, heavy, deliberate. Mom's eyes went wide. She mouth 9, 1, 1. But her phone was downstairs in her purse. Mine was dead. The foot steps got closer. My 4, 11. Mom pushed me behind her, grabbing my field hockey stick. The door swung open. A man in a ski mask stood there, knife glinting. Mom swung the stick, but he caught it, yanked it away, shoved her heart into the wall. I screamed. The closet door exploded open. Chemistry boy launched himself at the intruder using those same moves he taught me. They crashed into the hallway. Call 9, 1, 1, he yelled.

Parents who have adopted a older child, 5 and up. How has it gone for you? When my wife Rachel and I adopted Devon at six years old, they told us she had mild trust issues. What they didn't tell us was that she'd been returned by three families already. Devon showed up at our house with one tiny suitcase and a backpack that first night. I watched her through the doorway as she carefully laid out all her clothes on the bed. She folded each piece perfectly, put it back in the suitcase, and zipped it up. Then she slept on top of the covers, fully dressed. I thought maybe she was just nervous, but weeks went by, and that suitcase never got unpacked. We take out one outfit each morning, wear it all day, then fold it back up at night. Her closet stayed completely empty. Rachel tried everything. New sheets with unicorns on them, a night light shaped like a butterfly. We even let her pick out paint for her room walls. He chose white. Just plain white like before. One morning, I found her in the kitchen at 5 a m. Making her own breakfast. Toast with no butter. Just dry bread. When I asked why she was up so early, she said, I didn't want to bother you guys. Sometimes people get mad when kids wake them up. That broke my heart. Rachel and I had been trying for years to have kids. We dreamed About Saturday morning pancakes and bedtime stories. But Devin acted like she was living in a hotel, not a home. The real wake up call came three months later. I got home from work and heard crying upstairs. I found Devon sitting on her bed, holding that stupid suitcase in her lap. What's wrong, sweetheart? She looked up at me with these huge brown eyes and said, I heard you and Rachel fighting last night about money. I know kids cost a lot. I can go back to Miss Janet tomorrow if you want. Miss Janet was her social worker. My throat got tight. Rachel and I had been arguing about our car payment. Nothing to do with Devon at all. Devon, we weren't fighting about you. We love having you here. She just shrugged. That's what the Johnson said, too. And the Millers. They all said I was special. Until I wasn't anymore. That night, Rachel and I sat up talking until 3 a m. We realized Devon wasn't just scared of us leaving her. She was waiting for us to leave her. She'd been through this routine before. Nice family, happy faces. Then back to foster care. When things got tough the next day, I had an idea. I went to the hardware store and bought the biggest picture frame they had, like three feet wide. Then Rachel and I spent the whole weekend taking photos. Devon at breakfast, Devon watching TV, Devon playing with our dog, Charlie. Just normal, boring family stuff. We printed out all the pictures and arranged them in the frame. Beach trips we took her on. Movie nights on the couch. Devon's first day at her new school. Even the bad pictures where someone was making a weird face. When Devon got home from school Monday, we called her into the living room.

How did your daughter react to her first period? It's 7:00am. I'm still half asleep with coffee when my daughter bust into the bathroom like the FBI. She's holding her underwear up like a bloody flag and screaming, mom, I'm leaking from the wrong end! I'm gonna die! I nearly spit coffee everywhere. I say, sweetheart, calm down. That's just your period. She freezes, squints at me and yells, you liar! I knew you made that story up few months ago. I actually explained this whole thing Saturday down. Gave her the talk, showed her pictures. She rolled her eyes and said, nice prank, mom. You really think I'm that dumb? Now she's standing here like I faked the whole biology system just to mess with her. She stomps her foot. So you mean to tell me women eat every month and just go to target like nothing happened? She's pacing, yelling, you could have stopped this! You're my mom, not my enemy! I hand her a pad. She picks it up with two fingers like it's radioactive. This is a diaper. You want me to wear a diaper to school? Kids already bully me for my Lunchables. If I sound like a Doritos bag when I walk, I'm done. She sticks it on, takes two steps. Crunch, crunch! She stops, dead serious. Perfect. Now I'm Miss Fritos. Then she whispers, wait, does dad get this, too? I almost choked on my coffee. No, baby, only girls! She screams. Figures. Men don't do anything. They just fart and watch football while we bleed like stabbed pumpkins. She comes home from school later, furious. Mom, you didn't warn me the pad sticks to your leg hair. I was in that stall fighting for my life. People thought I was wrestling a raccoon. Then she adds, and when I sneezed in math, I thought my kidney fell out. Thanks, mom. Now they call me Leaky Lindsay. That night, she's on the couch, blanket eating pad, hot Cheetos in her lap, looking like a soldier who saw combat. She points at her brother and yells, enjoy your balls, loser! My. This is literally trying to kill me. He cried into his Pop Tarts. Next morning, she tries to get out of chores. Mom, I can't clean. My uterus is in critical condition. I say, nope. She glares at me, wow, you're a woman, too? And you still betrayed me. You're basically a war criminal. At dinner, my husband's carving chicken. It's calm. Suddenly, she stands up, bangs her glass with a fork, and goes, ladies and gentlemen, I am now a woman. My uterus has joined the group chat. Please clap. My husband choked on a drumstick. My son screamed, gross! And ran upstairs. And the grand finale. She whips out a Sharpie, lifts her shirt, and across her stomach she's written in giant letters, congrats, dad! You're next! I nearly passed out laughing. My husband dropped his fork like he saw a Ghost! My son slammed his door, and my daughter, she just sat back down, grabbed mashed potatoes with her hands, and goes. Period season has officially started, bitches.
